"We would welcome their participation in developing these industries in Hong Kong," he said.

On Monday, Mr Tung flies to the Canadian capital Ottawa for meetings with Prime Minister Jean Chretien, Foreign Minister Lloyd Axworthy and Finance Minister Paul Martin.

Mr Tung will also hold talks with the Canada-Hong Kong Parliamentary Friendship Group and attend a briefing and demonstration at a high-tech company.

On Tuesday, Mr Tung returns to Toronto where he will deliver two keynote speeches - a luncheon address to more than 800 business, political, academic and Chinese community leaders and a dinner function to be attended by about 200 of Canada's top corporate executives.

Mr Tung is also due to meet Toronto Mayor Mel Lastman and receive a briefing on environmental issues by state and local government officials.

Photo: The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, and Mrs Tung are greeted by China's Ambassador to Canada, Mr Mei Ping, and his wife Mei Lin Sa, after arriving in Toronto.
19991218_003.e:
Chief Executive Received International Visitors

The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, met with three visitors who were passing through Hong Kong en route to attend the Handover Ceremony and related events in Macao this afternoon (Saturday).

They are the Princess of Thailand, Her Royal Highness Princess Maha Chakri Sirindhorn, the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs of Belgium, Mr Louis Michel, and the European Commissioner in charge of External Relations, Mr Christopher Patten.

The Chief Executive recalled the visit of Her Royal Highness to attend the Handover Ceremony in 1997 and warmly welcomed her visiting Hong Kong again.

With the Deputy Prime Minister of Belgium, Mr. Tung said that with China's expected accession to the World Trade Organisation, Hong Kong would continue to provide a most important springboard for Belgian companies to invest in the Mainland.

At the meeting with the European Commissioner, Mr Patten, the Chief Executive noted that EU was our third largest trading partner in the world in 1998.

Mr. Tung believed that bilateral trade and investment relations would grow even stronger.

The Chief Executive said that Hong Kong had always supported China's accession to WTO.

This would be important to the Hong Kong economy and we hoped that the European Union would reach agreement with China at an early date.

Turning to increased travel convenience for Hong Kong people, Mr Tung said that a visa-free policy towards HKSAR passport holders would be beneficial to the promotion of trade, economic and tourism ties between Hong Kong and the EU.

Mr Tung hoped that the European Commission would support granting visa-free access to holders of HKSAR passports.

Photo: The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, met with the Princess of Thailand, Her Royal Highness Princess Maha Chakri Sirindhorn, the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs of Belgium, Mr Louis Michel, and the European Commissioner in charge of External Relations, Mr Christopher Patten, at separate meetings.

The three visitors are passing through Hong Kong en route to attend the Handover Ceremony and related events in Macao.

The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, photographed with the Belgian Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs, Mr Louis Michel, at the Chief Executive's Office after a meeting.
19990926_013.e:
Chief Executive leaves for Shanghai

The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, has left for Shanghai today (Sunday) to attend the 1999 Fortune Global Forum.

"Mr Tung will participate in the Forum as a member of the VIP delegation of the Central People's Government," a Government spokesman said.

While in Shanghai, Mr Tung will attend the welcome reception and the gala dinner of the Forum to be held tomorrow evening.

The Chief Executive will be accompanied by Mrs Tung; and the Director of Beijing Office, Mr Bowen Leung.

Mr Tung will return to Hong Kong on September 28.
19991118_010.e:
Chief Executive's duty visit to Beijing

The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, will leave for Beijing on Sunday (November 21) for his annual duty visit, a Government spokesman announced today (Thursday).

Mr Tung will return on November 22.

During his stay, Mr Tung will call on President Jiang Zemin, Premier Zhu Rongji and Vice Premier Qian Qichen.

The Chief Executive will be accompanied by the Information Coordinator, Mr Stephen Lam; Private Secretary to the Chief Executive, Mr Richard Yuen; and Special Assistant to the Chief Executive, Mr Chan Kin-ping.

He will also be accompanied by Mrs Tung.

During the absence of Mr Tung, the Financial Secretary will assume the duties of the Chief Executive.
19990303_057.e:
Chief Executive leaves for Beijing tomorrow

The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, will leave for Beijing tomorrow (Thursday) morning.

At 4 pm tomorrow, Mr Tung will host a cocktail reception in Xi Da Ting (the West Hall) of The Great Hall of the People to mark the official opening of the Beijing Office of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region.

The Vice Premier, Mr Qian Qichen, will be the principal officiating guest at the opening ceremony.

At the invitation of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, the Chief Executive will attend the opening ceremony of the second session of the Ninth National People's Congress on Friday (March 5).

Mr Tung will have other engagements and meetings with officials of the Central Government on Friday and Saturday before returning to Hong Kong on Saturday evening.

Accompanying Mr Tung on the visit will be the Information Coordinator, Mr Stephen Lam; the Private Secretary to the Chief Executive, Mr Joshua Law; and Special Assistant to the Chief Executive, Mr Chan Kin-ping.

The Chief Executive will also be accompanied by Mrs Tung.

END/Wednesday, March 3, 1999
19990708_020.e:
Chief Executive to visit US

The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, will visit San Francisco and the Silicon Valley on July 21 and 22 respectively, a Government spokesman announced today (Thursday).

In San Francisco, Mr Tung will call on the Mayor of the City and meet with business and community leaders.

He will visit a number of information technology companies in the Silicon Valley.

"The Chief Executive will take the opportunity of the visit to brief his interlocutors in the US on the latest developments in Hong Kong.

He will emphasise Hong Kong's advantages as a business and service centre, and the importance the SAR attaches to the development of IT and other high value-added industries," the spokesman said.

Accompanying the Chief Executive on the visit will be the Secretary for Trade and Industry, Mr Chau Tak Hay; the Information Coordinator, Mr Stephen Lam; the Director-General of Industry, Mr Francis Ho; the Deputy Secretary for Information Technology and Broadcasting, Ms Eva Cheng; and the Private Secretary to the Chief Executive, Mr Joshua Law.

The Chief Executive will also be accompanied by Mrs Tung.
19990202_028.e:
CE seeks Israel's secrets of high-tech success

The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, yesterday (Monday, HK time) said he hopes to learn the 'secrets of success' of Israel's high-tech industries during his landmark three-day visit to the country.

On his first official day of engagements, Mr Tung received a warm welcome from Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Israeli Foreign Minister Ariel Sharon and President Ezer Weizman.

Speaking during a lunch hosted by Mr Sharon, the Chief Executive said: "I'm here to see for myself first hand how Israel has become successful and also to see for myself especially in areas of innovation of technology which have impressed almost everybody around the world.

"I hope during my trip my colleagues and I will have the time to study the secrets of your success and that there will also be opportunities for our private sectors to work together."

Mr Tung repeated this theme during his meeting with Mr Netanyahu, noting that Hong Kong's economic base could be broadened through the commercialisation of new and innovative technology.

"I'm sure we will see and learn a lot during our next two days when we visit your universities, companies and centres for technology development," Mr Tung said during his meeting with Mr Netanyahu.

Prime Minister Netanyahu said the Chief Executive's visit set a wonderful precedent for growing relations between Hong Kong and Israel.

He said a major investment by a Hong Kong telecommunications company had 'changed the face' of the cellular phone market in Israel and he was expecting to see 'many, many more' investments from Hong Kong.

"Hong Kong has been, for many of us, a model of the application of free-market principles in a small place," he said.

"I believe your population is about six million and with a per capita income amongst the highest in the world - about US$25,000.

"We're moving up to US$18,000 and we'll try to the best of our abilities to catch you but in this endeavour we are not competitors we are partners.

"You should know we welcome your visit here, you personally and your delegation.

And the more we do business the better and better."

Mr Tung started his first full day's programme in Jerusalem with a breakfast meeting with Israel's President Ezer Weizman at which a wide range of issues were discussed including Hong Kong's reunification, the Asian financial turmoil, Israel's high-tech development and the ongoing peace process in the region.

Following the breakfast meeting, Mr Tung visited the grave of the late Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, where he and Mrs Tung laid a wreath and, in line with Jewish tradition, placed a small stone on the grave as a symbol of their visit.

The Hong Kong delegation later visited the Martyrs' and Heroes' Memorial of the Holocaust, where Mr Tung laid a wreath in Remembrance Hall to commemorate the six million Jews murdered by the Nazi regime during World War II.

The group then visited United Nations Hill, a scenic vantage point overlooking the old and new sections of Jerusalem as well as the former Israel-Jordan border area from 1948 to 1967.

From there, Mr Tung and the Hong Kong delegation visited Mt Zion, where they were shown the Tomb of King David as well as the room where Jesus Christ is said to have taken the Last Supper.

Following the lunch with Mr Sharon and the meeting with Mr Netanyahu, Mr Tung visited the Israel Museum where he viewed sacred scriptures such as the Dead Sea Scrolls.

Later today Mr Tung will meet Israel's Industry and Trade Minister Natan Sharansky and the governor of the Bank of Israel Professor Ya'acov Frenkel before leaving for Tel Aviv and a series of in-depth briefings on Israel's high-tech development and industries.
19990201_019.e:
CE in Jerusalem for landmark visit to Israel

The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, arrived in Jerusalem yesterday (Sunday) to start a landmark three-day visit to Israel - the first by a serving head of government from Hong Kong.

Mr Tung's trip will focus on Israel's development of high-tech industries, which account for about two-thirds of the country's exports.

Joining Mr Tung on the trip are Secretary for Trade and Industry Chau Tak Hay, Director-General of Industry Francis Ho and Hong Kong business delegates Raymond Ch'ien, Inchcape Pacific chairman; David Wong, Dah Sing Bank chairman; and Richard Li, Pacific Century Group chairman.

Mr Tung and the Hong Kong team started their visit yesterday with a tour of Jerusalem's historic Old City.

The official programme starts today (Monday) with a day of political and ceremonial calls.

These will include meetings with Israel's President Ezer Weizman, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and the Minister of Foreign Affairs Ariel Sharon.

Mr Tung will lay wreaths at the Memorial of the Holocaust and at the grave of the late Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, as well as visit the Israel Museum to view ancient manuscripts such as the Dead Sea Scrolls.

On Tuesday, Mr Tung will meet Israel's Minister for Industry and Trade, Mr Natan Sharansky, hold luncheon talks with Bank of Israel Governor Professor Ya'acov Frenkel and visit a centre for drug design and development.

On Tuesday afternoon, Mr Tung and the Hong Kong team leaves for Tel Aviv for a briefing on the Israeli government's support of industry research and development.

On Wednesday, the Chief Executive will visit satellite, multi-media and telecommunications companies, a scientific institute and a facility which nurtures technological innovation and entrepreneurs.

19981129_006.e:
New fire safety legislation in the pipeline

The Government is studying how to improve the fire safety standards of all composite buildings by introducing new legislation, the Secretary for Security, Mrs Regina Ip, said today (Sunday).

Speaking at the launching ceremony of the annual Fire Prevention Campaign 1998/99 at the Hong Kong Cultural Centre Piazza, Mrs Ip said the new fire safety legislation was expected to be enacted in the 1999/2000 legislative session.

"Besides stepping up enforcement actions to ensure that property owners or management bodies would upkeep and improve the fire service structures and installations of their buildings, we will raise the fire safety awareness of the community," Mrs Ip said.

She said the Government had strengthened publicity on building management to encourage property owners to look into the fire safety of their buildings.

The Fire Services Department (FSD) had also expanded the Fire Safety Ambassador Scheme and its membership would be increased from 1 500 to 4 000 by the end of the year, Mrs Ip said.

She added that the FSD planned to recruit caretakers to become Fire Safety Ambassadors through the Home Affairs Department and local community organisations next year.

Also at the ceremony, the Director of Fire Services, Mr John Tsang Kwong-yu, said it was everyone's responsibility to prevent fires.

He said: "We can all help eliminate fire risks by keeping means of escape free of obstruction, making sure that smoke stop doors are closed and exit doors unlocked."

Mr Tsang urged the management of each organisation to actively promote fire safety awareness among its staff and arrange various fire safety activities such as fire drills and talks.

"Our department joined the Institution of Fire Engineers to stage the Fire Asia 98 conference and exhibition last week with the aim of promoting fire safety culture and exploring the latest fire service management skills," Mr Tsang said.

The delegates from various countries had exchanged the latest skills and experiences in fire services during the conference, and the local fire services personnel had also introduced the new knowledge and techniques to maintain Hong Kong's fire services technology at world standards, he added.

Programmes included water-jetting display by a fireboat, exhibition booths mounted by various government departments, performances by the Fire Services Chinese Musical Band, Commercial Radio artistes, TVB "Fire Safety Stars" and Fire Safety Ambassadors.
20000309_021.e:
Roving Exhibitions to promote Fire Safety

The Central Steering Committee on Fire Safety will organise a series of roving exhibitions in three shopping arcades in March and April.

To arouse public awareness on fire safety, the theme of Fire Safety Roving Exhibitions 1999/2000 will be on "Neighbourhood Assistance".

The contents of the exhibition include major causes of fire; fire risks in residential, commercial and industrial buildings; the Fire Safety (Commercial Premises) Ordinance; operation of the hose reel system; Fire Safety Ambassador Scheme; fire safety measures in private buildings and public housing estates; prevention of hill fire; role of security guards in preventing fire; and building management and fire safety.

Besides the display panels, a computer kiosk will be set up for visitors to take part in the fire safety computer quiz to see if they grasp the basic knowledge of fire safety.

Meanwhile, fire safety promotional videos will also be screened at the venues of the exhibitions.

The first exhibition will be staged at Discovery Park, Tsuen Wan from March 11 to 14, followed by an exhibition at Times Square, Causeway Bay, from March 24 to 26.

The last exhibition will be mounted at Lok Fu Shopping Centre from March 31 to April 5.
20000127_035.e:
Efforts to enhance community's awareness of fire safety

The Government and District Fire Safety Committees will continue their joint efforts to enhance the community's awareness of fire safety.

Speaking at a press briefing today (Thursday), the Deputy Director of Home Affairs, Mr Lui Hau-tuen said: "District Fire Safety Committees (DFSCs), set up in all 18 districts by the Home Affairs Department between March 1998 and mid-December 1999, play an important role in enhancing community involvement and public awareness of fire safety.

"The DFSCs have organised a variety of publicity and educational activities on fire safety in the districts including fire safety inspections, fire drills and demonstrations, fire safety talks and seminars, visits to fire stations, "Best Fire Safety Building" competitions, fire safety carnivals, and community involvement activities in hill fire prevention.

"They have also produced newsletters, publicity leaflets and booklets, videos and CD-Roms on fire safety for distribution in their districts.

"They have been very effective in disseminating the fire safety message to all sectors of the community," Mr Lui added.

"DFSCs from eight districts with cubicle apartments in private residential buildings, including Central and Western, Wan Chai, Eastern, Yau Tsim Mong, Sham Shui Po, Kwun Tong, Tsuen Wan and Kwai Tsing, also help spread the fire safety message among residents of cubicle apartments.

"In view of the living conditions and insufficient fire safety installations in cubicle apartments, residents should take extra fire precautions for the sake of safety of their own lives and properties.

"They should not store excessive fuel for cooking purposes, should always keep a clear fire access and be extra careful in using electrical appliances," Mr Lui said.

"The DFSCs in all 18 districts will continue their efforts to support the fire safety Campaign and to organise activities to cater for the needs of residents in their districts," Mr Lui added.

Also meeting the media today were the Chief Fire Officer (Fire Safety) of the Fire Services Department, Mr Allan Lee and representatives of DFSCs from the eight districts.
19981123_024.e:
Improvement programme to enhance fire safety

The Hong Kong Government has formulated a comprehensive improvement programme to enhance fire safety, the Secretary for Security, Mrs Regina Ip, said today (Monday).

The programme included strengthening the legislative and administrative framework to upgrade fire safety facilities in old buildings, stepping up inspections and enforcement actions, and promoting a fire safety culture among the building management profession in particular and the community in general, Mrs Ip said.

Speaking at the opening ceremony of the Fire Asia' 98 Conference and Exhibition, Mrs Ip said Hong Kong, like many other metropolitan cities, faced the problem of having many old buildings equipped with outdated or ill-maintained fire service installations.

The Hong Kong Fire Services Department (FSD) would step up enforcement action to require buildings to reinstate defective or missing fire service installations to approved standards, and to abate fire hazards, Mrs Ip said.

"In 1999, the Department aims to conduct 7 000 inspections of private buildings to ensure that the fire safety requirements are complied with.

"It will also review the Fire Services Ordinance to strengthen its enforcement against fire hazards," Mrs Ip added.

While the Government would do its part to strengthen the legislative framework and step up enforcement action, Mrs Ip stressed that the community should contribute by maintaining their fire safety installations and reporting identified fire hazards.

"We will raise the fire safety awareness of the community through enhanced publicity and promotion of community involvement in the fight against fire," she said.

The FSD will conduct 1 600 fire drills for building owners and occupants and organise 2 200 seminars, exhibitions and talks on fire safety in the coming year.

Among the various new initiatives, Mrs Ip said a Fire Safety Ambassador Scheme was introduced which was mainly targeted at the younger generation.

Members of the Scouts Association of Hong Kong and the Hong Kong Red Cross will be trained and appointed as Fire Safety Ambassadors who will help report fire hazards to the FSD and convey fire safety messages to the general public.

Mrs Ip said: "Another key component of our fight fire policy is to help building owners to help themselves.

"We encourage and assist owners to manage their buildings properly.

We have prepared a Fire Safety Checklist to facilitate owners or occupants to carry out routine inspections on fire safety provisions of their own buildings and to rectify minor irregularities identified," Mrs Ip said.

A Building Management Resource Centre was established in June this year to provide information, services and advice for building owners, residents, Owners Corporations, Mutual Aid Committees and management bodies so as to assist them in improving the standards of management, safety and maintenance of their buildings.

The President of the Hong Kong Branch of the Institution of Fire Engineers (IFE), Mr John Tsang Kwong-yu, said this was the fourth time that an international fire engineering conference was being held in Hong Kong.

He said: "Through the 30 sessions of talks, workshops and case studies in this 3-day Conference, we will study the various approaches made in eastern and western countries in enhancing the fire safety of old buildings and will attempt to develop an integrated approach to raise their fire safety standards."

The Fire Asia' 98 is jointly organised by the Hong Kong Branch of the IFE and the United Kingdom-based Loss Prevention Council, and is supported by the Hong Kong FSD.

Speakers from the Mainland included the Director of the Fire Department, General Sun Lun; and the Deputy Chief of the Scientific Division, Mr Gao Wei; both from the Public Security Ministry.

They are joined by representatives from other countries including Belgium, Canada, Japan, Malaysia, the United Kingdom and United States.

More than 200 delegates including about 40 fire chiefs from a number of eastern and western countries attended the

3-day conference held at the new extension of the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre.

The theme of the conference is "Strive for a safer world - an integrated experience."
19981027_020.e:
Fire safety begins with you

The Fire Safety Roving Exhibitions was launched today (Tuesday.

The exhibition will be staged in five shopping malls throughout Hong Kong in the coming months.

Director of Fire Services (Designate), Mr Tsang Kwong-yu urged the public to pay attention to the importance of fire safety and announced the theme for the year to be "Fire Safety and I" during the opening ceremony.

"It is everyone's responsibility to prevent fire.

We can all help eliminate fire risks by keeping means of escape free of obstruction, making sure smoke stop doors are closed and exit doors unlocked.

In this way, we can protect our lives and property," he said.

Mr Tsang added that the roving exhibition series was part of the efforts of the Government to promote fire safety messages and was organised by the Central Steering Committee on Fire Safety.

The exhibition is about major causes of fire, fire hazards in industrial, commercial and residential premises; fire service installation and equipment, fire safety and building safety improvement loan scheme, fire safety ambassador scheme, fire safety on building construction, fire safety and building management and how security guards may prevent fire.

A programme on fire safety produced by RTHK is also screened in the exhibition.

The first exhibition of the series is staged at Times Square, Causeway Bay from October 27 onwards for three days, followed by exhibition at Hollywood Plaza, Diamond Hill on 6 November.

The exhibition will also be mounted at New Century Place, Mong Kok, Shatin New Town Plaza and Metroplaza, Kwai Fong.

Besides the roving exhibitions, Fire Services Department is organising other promotion activities on fire safety.

"Our department has joined hands with the Institution of Fire Engineers (Hong Kong Branch) to launch the Fire Asia 98, the main objective is to promote fire safety culture and to explore latest fire service management skills," Mr Tsang said.

Also attending the opening ceremony today were Deputy Secretary for Security, Ms Chang King-yiu; Deputy Director of Buildings, Mr Cheng Wei-dart; Deputy Director of Home Affairs, Mr Lui Hau-tuen and Assistant Director of Information Services, Mr Joe Yiu.
19980621_002.e:
Fire safety begins at home

Citizens in Hong Kong should work together to maintain and upkeep fire safety measures, the Secretary for Home Affairs, Mr David Lan, said today (Sunday).

Mr Lan made the appeal at the opening ceremony of the Fire Safety Publicity Campaign 1998/99 this afternoon.

"It is the responsibility of property owners and residents to protect their lives and property by maintaining fire safety measures," he said.

Mr Lan said that a Central Steering Committee on Fire Safety was set up.

Its membership consists of six bureau secretaries and department heads as well as seven non-official members to strengthen policies, education and publicity on fire safety.

The Fire Safety Publicity Campaign was launched under the Committee and was co-organised by Home Affairs Bureau, Security Bureau, Planning, Environment and Lands Bureau, Fire Services Department, Buildings Department, Home Affairs Department and Information Services Department.

The Director of Fire Services, Mr Peter Cheung, who was also present today, hoped that the public's awareness on the need of fire safety measures and their understanding of the destructive power of fire could be increased through a series of promotion activities.

"We have disseminated through negative figure 'Fire Devil' and positive image 'Fire Safety Star' the essence of fire safety messages," he said.

During the opening ceremony, local TV artistes Mr Louis Koo, Miss Esther Kwan, Mr Waise Lee and Miss Jay Leung literally played the part of "Fire Safety Stars" and demonstrated how to combat the "Fire Devil".

The "Fire Devil" with the slogan "Fire Kills Prevent Fire" would be carried in a series of publicity items including a new Television Announcement in the Public Interest (TV API), poster, leaflet, booklet, and stickers.

The TV API was premiered today.

Promotion activities on fire safety would also be launched by Home Affairs Department and Fire Services Department.

"We will have more concerted inter-departmental clearance operations to remove obstructions in means of escape and more Fire Safety Committees on district level," Mr David Lan said.

"An unprecedented Building Management Resource Centre would be opened soon to provide professional services to property owners, residents and Owners' Corporations," he added.

"One of our major programmes is the Fire Safety Ambassador Scheme.

We have already trained 438 tutors and 289 ambassadors up till May.

They will help prevent fire and deliver messages on fire safety to the public," Mr Peter Cheung said.

"We have already organised 283 talks, nine exhibitions and 62 fire drills to educate the public on fire safety and what to do in case of fire," he said.

Also attending the opening ceremony today were acting Director of Buildings, Mr Cheng Wei-dart; Deputy Director of Home Affairs, Mr Lui Hau-tuen; Deputy Secretary for Security, Ms Chang King-yiu; Assistant Director of Information Services, Mr Joe Yiu; and Principal Assistant Secretary for Planning, Environment and Lands, Mr Esmond Lee.
19990505_028.e:
District committees to promote fire safety culture

The Government has been actively promoting a fire safety culture, reinforcing building management bodies and enhancing public awareness of fire prevention through the setting up of District Fire Safety Committees (DFSCs), the Deputy Director of Home Affairs, Mr Lui Hau-tuen said today (Wednesday).

Mr Lui made the remarks at the inaugural meeting of the Yuen Long District Fire Safety Committee, which is one of the four DFSCs set up today.

Mr Lui also attended two other DFSC inaugural meetings in the North and Kwai Tsing districts, while another Deputy Director of Home Affairs, Mr Augustine Cheng attended the DFSC inaugural meeting in Wong Tai Sin.

Mr Lui said a Central Steering Committee on Fire Safety had been established to co-ordinate the efforts of various departments to promote fire safety.

"So far, a total of 16 DFSCs have been set up by the Home Affairs Department (HAD) to co-ordinate and organise fire safety activities at the district level and to enhance public awareness of the importance of fire safety.

"Sai Kung and Islands districts are expected to set up their DFSCs in December so that all 18 districts will have their own DFSC by the end of the year," Mr Lui said.

"The HAD plans to organise 80 publicity events on fire safety and building management for 10,000 participants and produce related publicity materials such as leaflets, booklets, TV and Radio Announcements of Public Interest in 1999 - 2000.

"The participation of DFSC members in fire safety publicity events including fire drills, training courses, talks, seminars and exhibitions are found to be very effective in bringing home the fire safety message," he added.

Mr Lui noted that the HAD had, in conjunction with relevant departments, devised a Fire Safety Checklist in layman's terms to facilitate and encourage owners and occupants to carry out routine inspections of the fire safety provisions of their buildings and to rectify promptly the irregularities identified.

So far, more than 130,000 copies of the Checklist had been distributed.

The HAD had also employed temporary staff to help promote fire safety including visiting Owners' Corporations (OC), Mutual Aid Committees (MAC) and building management bodies to distribute and promote the Checklist as well as assisting owners and occupants in conducting self-inspection of buildings by using the Checklist.

Attending the Wong Tai Sin DFSC inaugural meeting, Mr Cheng said: "As the educational and publicity programme on fire safety is an on-going task, its success depends a lot on the valuable advice and active participation of all DFSC members.

"With the concerted efforts of DFSCs and departments concerned, we hope to achieve the goal of enhancing public awareness of fire safety and tackle the problems of fire safety and building management in private buildings."

During the inaugural meetings, all the established DFSCs had pledged to tender advice on preventing hill fire, in addition to tendering advice on multi-storey buildings and residential areas in both the urban areas and the New territories.

Mr Lui and Mr Cheng presented appointment certificates to unofficial members who are either provisional district board members, Area Committee chairmen, OC chairmen, MAC chairmen, local community leaders or interested individuals from various professions.

Official members of DFSCs are representatives from the relevant departments.
20000126_017.e:
LCQ17: Fire and building safety of buildings with cubicles

Following is a question by the Hon Ma Fung-kwok and a written reply by the Secretary for Home Affairs, Mr David Lan, in the Legislative Council today (Wednesday):

Question :

Regarding the number, fire service installations and safety of cubicle apartments in private residential buildings, will the Government inform this Council whether:

(a) it has conducted surveys to find out the average number of cubicle apartments for separate occupation in private residential buildings in each of the past three years; whether the figures show an upward trend in the number of cubicle apartments; if so, of the reasons for that, and whether the increase in the number of new arrivals is one of the reasons;

(b) there is any legislation governing the fire service installations required in premises which have been partitioned into a number of cubicles; if there is, whether it plans to enhance law enforcement actions; if there are such plans, of the relevant details; if there is no such legislation, whether it will consider introducing legislation to that effect; and

(c) it has plans for stepping up promotional efforts to raise fire safety awareness among residents in cubicle apartments?

Reply:

Madam President,

My reply to the three parts of the question is as follows-

(a) we have not conducted specific surveys of cubicle apartments but in the General Household Survey conducted by the Census and Statistics Department in the third quarter of 1999, about 77000 households (population : 167000) were found to be living in non self-contained quarters in private buildings or rooftop quarters.

We have no information on the correlation between the number of cubicle apartments and new arrivals;

(b) regulatory controls of building and fire safety of private buildings are undertaken by the Buildings Department (BD) and Fire Services Department (FSD).

If cubicles adversely affect the structure of a building, or if the means of escape are compromised, enforcement action will be taken as a matter of priority by BD under the Buildings Ordinance.

FSD has statutory power under the Fire Services Ordinance to abate fire hazards, the overwhelming majority of which exist in the common parts of buildings.

Examples of fire hazards include obstruction to means of escape, and defective or missing fire service installations and equipment.

We consider that vigorous enforcement of the existing Ordinances is adequate to regulate the fire and building safety of private buildings containing cubicles and therefore we do not consider it necessary to introduce a separate legislation for the purpose at this stage; and

(c) we have an ongoing plan of promoting fire safety awareness among owners and residents of buildings as follows-

1. Under the auspices of the Central Steering Committee on Fire Safety chaired by me, the Home Affairs Department (HAD) has an ongoing publicity programme to promote effective building management and fire safety.

2. From March 1998 to mid-December 1999, District Fire Safety Committees (DFSCs) were established in all 18 Districts in Hong Kong.

DFSCs play an important role to help promote a fire safety culture in the community.

3. On 5 December 1999, FSD in conjunction with the Information Services Department conducted a major fire prevention campaign at the Hong Kong Cultural Centre Piazza.

The main theme of the campaign was "¦u±æ¬Û§U,°µ¦n¨¾¤õ".

As a continuation of this campaign, a series of high profile fire safety publicity activities are being conducted at major shopping malls and public housing estates throughout Hong Kong.

4. In addition, in an effort to raise public awareness of fire safety, FSD conducted over 2000 fire protection talks and organized 612 fire drills for building owners, occupiers and property management companies in the last 12 months.

FSD has published an information booklet entitled "Fire Prevention in the Home" for handing out to the general public at the fire safety publicity activities.

5. HAD also published a "Fire Safety Checklist" to facilitate owners and occupiers to carry out self-inspection of fire safety provisions of their buildings.

The checklist has been well received by the public.

These checklists and the FSD's booklets mentioned above are available free of charge at the District Offices and Building Management Resource Centres of HAD.

The above publicity and education efforts have enhanced the community's awareness of fire safety and benefited building owners and occupants, including those living in cubicle apartments.

These efforts will continue vigorously.
19971217_022.e:
Fire safety of old buildings 

Following is a question by the Hon Kennedy Wong Ying- ho and a written reply by the Secretary for Security, Mr Peter Lai, in the Provisional Legislative Council today (Wednesday):

Question:

As the fire-fighting facilities in some older buildings in the territory are below the fire safety standard, in the present dry season of high risk of fire, will the Government inform this Council:

(a) of the immediate measures in place to lower the fire hazards of these buildings; and

(b) whether consideration has been given to improving, by legislative means, the fire-fighting facilities in these buildings, such as requiring a greater number of fire extinguishers and the provision of fire- proof blankets?

Reply:

Madam President,

(a) Older buildings in the territory were constructed according to the fire safety standards at the time when they were built.

However, it does not mean that those buildings are of a high risk of fire, if their fire safety installation and equipment are properly maintained, and that the owners and occupiers take adequate fire safety precautions and observe fire safety.

To ensure that proper fire safety measures are taken, the Fire Services Department (FSD) has stepped up inspections during the dry season.

In October and November 1997, FSD conducted 2,540 inspections to commercial buildings, 1,513 to residential buildings and 524 to industrial buildings.

Fire Hazard Abatement Notices will be issued to order the removal of any fire hazards identified.

The Buildings Department (BD) has conducted 598 inspections to pre-1973 old commercial buildings since May 1997, and has issued 5,823 advisory letters to the owners to encourage them to improve the fire safety conditions of their buildings.

The Labour Department (LD) has been launching a fire safety inspection campaign from October 16, 1997 to December 31, 1997.

This is an intensive law enforcement exercise concentrating on work places where accidents are prone to happen.

Immediate prosecutions will be initiated by the factory inspectors of the LD when serious potential fire risks are detected.

LD also conducted joint inspections with FSD to 36 pre-1973 industrial buildings in early 1997 and 500 advisory letters were sent.

To raise the fire safety awareness of the public during the dry season, FSD launched the 1997/98 fire prevention campaign with the theme "Fire Safety in Commercial and Industrial Buildings" in November 1997.

A series of seminars and activities will be held for the general public to convey fire safety knowledge and message to them.

The Home Affairs Department has frequent contacts with building management bodies, owners' corporations and mutual aid committees to promote fire safety.

The FSD complaint hotline is frequently publicised for the public to report fire hazards to the department.

The LD also organises promotional activities on fire safety at work and publishes booklets and leaflets on fire safety at workplaces frequently.

(b) The Government will introduce legislation to improve the fire safety standard of old commercial buildings.

We are planning to extend the scope of the Fire Safety (Commercial Premises) Ordinance to require the installation of additional fire service installations and equipment (including automatic sprinkler system, fire hydrant/hosereel system and emergency lighting), and improvements to building structure in respect of means of escape, means of access and fire resisting construction in old commercial buildings.

Drafting of the legislation is in progress and we aim to introduce the bill into the Provisional Legislative Council in early 1998.

En
19981021_009.e:
Committee focusing on fire safety

The Secretary for Home Affairs, Mr David Lan, today (Wednesday) stressed the need to promote a fire safety culture among members of the public in view of the dry weather in the coming months.

Speaking at a press briefing following a meeting of the Central Steering Committee on Fire Safety today (Wednesday), Mr Lan said the No. 3 alarm fire in Ngau Tau Kok Road on Monday (October 19) had highlighted the urgency for owners and tenants to comply with building and fire safety regulations.

Referring to the announcement in this year's Policy Address, Mr Lan said the Government aimed to introduce legislation in 1999 to require the upgrading of fire safety in composite buildings.

The Fire Services Department (FSD) will issue advisory letters to encourage owners to improve fire safety before legislation is in place.

Enforcement action to require compliance with existing legislation will continue to be stepped up.

Mr Lan said the FSD had been stepping up inspections in private buildings, particularly composite (commercial/residential) buildings, in view of their higher fire risks.

The FSD has been following up on the fire hazards identified in a territory-wide building survey.

Up to August 31, more than 2,700 Fire Hazard Abatement Notices have been issued requiring responsible persons to remove the hazards.

The Electrical and Mechanical Services Department (EMSD) will step up inspection of electrical installation in buildings to ensure compliance with the relevant safety requirements.

Mr Lan said the Government planned to organise another large-scale fire safety publicity campaign in 1999/2000 to further enhance public awareness of fire safety as well as to cultivate and sustain a fire safety culture in the community.

In order to promote the awareness of fire safety at district level, the Home Affairs Department (HAD) will speed up the establishment of District Fire Safety Committees (DFSCs) to disseminate the message of fire safety.

The DFSCs include representatives from all relevant government departments, local community leaders and professionals known for their expertise and interest in the subject.

The next batch of three DFSCs will be established in Kwun Tong, Tuen Mun and Wan Chai in December.

By the end of 1999, there will be DFSCs to cover all 18 districts.

Mr Lan also urged the public to make use of the Building Management Resource Centre (BMRC) set up in April this year.

Plans to open the second BMRC, to be located on Hong Kong Island, and the third one, in Tsuen Wan, are underway.

Meanwhile, the FSD has expanded the Fire Safety Ambassadors Scheme, with membership to increase from 1,500 to 4,000 by the end of this year.

The programme will be further expanded in 1999, with the FSD proposing to recruit caretakers as Ambassadors.

The meeting also discussed at length the outcome of a two-month public consultation launched in June this year to improve fire safety in private buildings.

Mr Lan told members that the Government would co-ordinate a programme for full implementation of proposals contained in the paper to improve fire safety in private buildings.

Members noted that the community was supportive of the objective to improve fire safety and building management in private buildings.

There was also general consensus that there existed a close correlation between good building management and fire safety, and that Bureaux and Departments should make concerted efforts on the following aspects:

* compulsory building management for problematic buildings;

* upgrading of fire safety standards in private buildings;

* removal of unauthorised building works affecting fire safety; and

* monitoring of maintenance of communal electrical installations in buildings.

Mr Lan said services rendered by the HAD on building management were generally recognised by the public.

The HAD will continue to improve and expand its services and assist building owners to solve building management problems as far as resources allow.

19990917_013.e:
HK Customs playing a significant role

The Commissioner of Customs and Excise, Mr John Tsang Chun-wah, said today (Friday) Hong Kong Customs had been playing a significant role in the implementation of the "one Country, two systems" concept in Hong Kong.

Mr Tsang was speaking at the Department's dinner party, one of the major events to mark the 90th anniversary of the Customs and Excise Department.

He noted that Hong Kong remained a separate Customs territory and that the Department's success in law enforcement had helped upholding the law and order in Hong Kong.

"At the same time, the Department strikes a fine balance in its role as law enforcement body with that of trade facilitation," Mr Tsang added.

Turning to the history of the Customs and Excise Department, he noted that it could be traced back to its predecessor, the Preventive Service, which was set up 90 years ago, on September 17, 1909, with a small establishment of 26 Revenue officers.

"With an establishment of 5,200 staff members, the Customs and Excise Department is now a major department under the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, committed to the enforcement of 48 different pieces of legislation," Mr Tsang went on.

Attending the dinner tonight were more than 1,200 staff members of the Customs and Excise Department and a number of retired Customs officers as well as some Customs attaches stationed in Hong Kong.
19991127_012.e:
Hong Kong to boost technology investment

As a cosmopolitan city, Hong Kong is keen to boost investment in technology and promote innovation.

This must go hand in hand with the establishment of a sound regime to ensure that intellectual property rights are properly protected.

The Financial Secretary, Mr Donald Tsang, made the remarks today (Saturday) when addressing a passing-out parade at the Customs and Excise Training School.

"Apart from improving our legislation, the key to protection of intellectual property rights is effective law-enforcement," he noted.

He pointed out that the Customs and Excise Department had always been dedicated in combating offences involving intellectual property rights.

"Your recent success has upheld Hong Kong's trading integrity at the international level and will certainly contribute to our long term economic development," Mr Tsang said.

He also noted that efforts of Customs officers against the illicit trade of dutiable goods at all levels had also achieved marvellous records pertaining to the protection of government revenue.

"You have risen to the challenges posed by the more complex illegal syndicates with effective enforcement strategies and an extensive intelligence network.

This has successfully contained the problem on illegal trade of dutiable cigarettes and hydrocarbon oil," he told the officers at the parade.

In order to strengthen co-operation with the international community on the anti-smuggling front, the SAR Government entered into a Customs Co-operation Agreement with the European Union in May this year, he went on.

"This will certainly further enhance your enforcement actions against cross-boundary smuggling activities," he added.

Mr Tsang, in conclusion, appealed to the new recruits to keep pace with the time and enhance their skill and knowledge to equip themselves for the challenges ahead, to sustain the momentum of the Department's good work, and to contribute to the stability and prosperity of the community.

Taking part in today's parade were 43 probationary inspectors and 64 probationary Customs officers.

Photo:The Financial Secretary, Mr Donald Tsang, taking the salute at a passing-out parade at the Customs and Training School.
20000303_021.e:
Customs Cooperative Arrangement signed

The Customs General Administration (CGA) of the People's Republic of China and the Hong Kong Customs and Excise Department have early this week signed a Customs Co-operative Arrangement which is aimed at strengthening the cooperation and mutual administrative assistance between the two Customs administrations.

Mr John Tsang Chun-wah, Commissioner of Customs and Excise represented the Department and Mr. Mu Xin-sheng, Deputy Commissioner of Customs General Administration represented the CGA to sign the Arrangement.

The Arrangement was formulated in accordance with the "Memorandum of Understanding on Co-operation" signed by both administrations in Beijing in August 1998.

In signing the Arrangement, both administrations follow the principles of the Basic Law and the framework of "One Country, Two Systems".

The signing of the Arrangement is another excellent example to demonstrate Hong Kong Customs Department's status as a separate customs territory.

The Arrangement provides a framework for both administrations to strengthen cooperation in the fight against smuggling; illicit drug trafficking and in the protection of intellectual property rights.

Besides, it sets out the mode of cooperation and the arrangements of mutual administrative assistance in other Customs related areas.

After signing the Arrangement, both administrations will exchange intelligence of cross-boundary smuggling, drug trafficking and copyright piracy, conduct joint anti-smuggling operation, organise visits and training programmes and conduct feasibility studies to simplify Customs clearance procedures and on the exchange of information through the electronic data interchange.

During their stay in Hong Kong, the delegation of Customs General Administration paid a courtesy call on the Secretary of Trade and Industry, Secretary for Security and Commissioner of Police.

They also visited the Customs and Excise Training School and the Customs Anti-Smuggling Marine Base.

The Customs General Administration delegation left Hong Kong today (Friday).
19990612_011.e:
Working procedures under constant review

The management of the Hong Kong Customs has been constantly reviewing the working procedures in order to minimise the chance for corruption.

This was said today (Saturday) by the Commissioner of Customs and Excise, Mr John Tsang Chun-wah, when inspecting a passing-out parade at the Customs and Excise Training School.

"Despite a few ICAC cases in which Customs officers were convicted, I am certain that the department remains honest and clean as a whole," Mr Tsang stressed.

He told the new recruits that he had directed the senior officers to attach importance to the well being of subordinates with a view to guarding against corruption and maintaining their good conduct.

The department had been working closely with ICAC in numerous collaborative efforts in combating against and preventing corruption, Mr Tsang added.

He said the Customs and Excise Department was a forward-looking, modern and progressive disciplined service.

"Since I took up the post of Commissioner, I have been deeply impressed by the high efficiency and professionalism being displayed by my colleagues," he said.

He noted that the department undertook a wide range of responsibilities, including collection and protection of revenue on dutiable goods, anti-smuggling and anti-narcotics work, protection of intellectual property rights and consumer interests, protection of legitimate trade and industry, trade controls and upholding of Hong Kong's trading integrity.

"The marvellous record we have gathered in these aspects has contributed a lot to maintaining Hong Kong's status as an international commercial and trading centre," he went on.

Mr Tsang, in conclusion, appealed to the new recruits to bear in mind that upholding the law and facilitating trade were their dual missions.

"While performing your duties, you have to be diligent, active and decisive.

What's more, you must strive for honesty and integrity in a bid to maintaining the good image of the department," he added.

Taking part in today's parade were 105 probationary Customs Officers.
19990909_011.e:
HK Customs fully committed to IPR protection

The Customs and Excise Department is fully committed to intellectual property rights (IPR) protection and will continue doing everything possible to maintain Hong Kong as a pirate-free zone.

The assurance was given by the Commissioner of Customs and Excise, Mr John Tsang Chun-wah, when addressing a luncheon of the Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce today (Thursday).

Mr Tsang, while outlining Customs work in curbing the rampant piracy activities, said, "I am very happy to tell you that we have blinded the pirate in the remaining eye.

The piracy situation is now under control."

He noted that the extent of CD piracy in Hong Kong was shrinking rapidly due to the hard work of the largest dedicated professional enforcement unit in the world.

"We take a two pronged enforcement strategy directed at the supply side and the retail end of the pirated CD business in our community," he said.

The Prevention of Copyright Piracy Ordinance came into force in August last year, requiring CD factories to operate under Customs licence.

"Having been assured of the legitimacy of our licensed factories, our investigation teams would turn to concentrate their energy on the underground plants," Mr Tsang noted.

He pointed out that since last September, Customs officers had cracked 11 underground CD factories and seized 18 production lines worth some $100 million.

"Without a local source, supply of pirated CDs to the local market now comes mainly from nearby areas, as evident by the upsurge in our interceptions made at the airport, land and marine boundaries," he went on.

So far this year, Customs officers had intercepted some 800,000 CDs at these boundary points, he noted.

"We are also putting tremendous pressure on pirated CD retail outlets in notorious shopping arcades," he said.

Apart from the 300 odd officers of the Intellectual Property Investigation Bureau, the Department has set up a 185-member Special Task Force to tackle the piracy problem on the street level.

The Special Task Force, drawing resources from other Customs formations to make up a 300 strong team on any major outing, launched its first territory-wide anti-piracy operation on June 30, Mr Tsang said.

"Up to the end of August, just in a mere two months' time, some 750 shops have been raided, over 600 people arrested, and two million pirated products seized," he added.

He noted that due to the heightened enforcement pressure against the sale of pirated CDs, officers of the Special Task Force had encountered increasing resistance by illicit operators.

Mr Tsang, however, maintained that the resistance would not affect morale of the officers but helped to strengthen their resolve.

Speaking on police involvement in tackling the retail sale of pirated and counterfeit goods, Mr Tsang said Customs had a close working relationship with the Police.

"Joint operations are mounted from time to time with raids at shopping arcades and hawking areas.

In addition, the Police and Customs have a standing arrangement of exchanging intelligence on IPR violations on a weekly basis," he added.

He noted that the use of repeated enforcement actions in the notorious black spots had proved its effectiveness.

"We have now broken the back of the illicit business in the popular areas.

Vendors of pirated CDs have been forced out of their mainstream bases to operate underground, or to resort to very short-term leases in long vacated premises.

"We intend to do even more on the legislative side to enhance our enforcement," he stressed.

The proposals, he cited, included amendments to make unauthorised recordings in cinemas an offence, to broaden the definition of infringing activities to include anything other than those intended for personal and domestic purposes, to incorporate copyright and counterfeiting offences into the Organised and Serious Crimes Ordinance for the purposes of attracting heavier penalties and forfeiture of monetary proceeds from such illegal activities.

"We are also considering other amendments which will help facilitate enforcement.

Obviously, the degree of severity of these measures would have to be acceptable to the public," he said.

On courts punishment, Mr Tsang said, "our courts also consider that IPR protection is critical for the protection of our society."

He added they had handed down heavy sentences to underline their resolve.

"Recent sentences reached as high as 39 months of imprisonment and $1.04 million of fine.

Both cases concerned manufacturing of infringing CDs," he noted.

Turning to the role played by the industry in protecting intellectual property, Mr Tsang emphasized that the success of their strategy rested with the commitment of the industry.

Customs was the sole enforcement agent for the statutory offences, he explained, adding that the primary responsibility for the protection of the rights rested invariable with the property rights owners who could take civil litigations against unauthorised exploitation of those rights.

"We maintain our already close working relationship with the industry," he said.

Customs has been managing the Anti-Piracy Reward Scheme funded by the industry since 1998 and some $1.3 million of reward money has been paid so far for information leading to successful prosecutions.

The Commissioner said the industry had been very supportive in general in helping the Department verify the authenticity of the seized CDs and provide the necessary administrative support in criminal prosecution.

"In June this year, we have jointly launched with the Business Software Alliance the Genuine Software Action Campaign to give recognition to organisations with good internal software management," he continued.

He noted that the programme had generated a great deal of interest in the community.

Mr Tsang noted that the piracy problem could not be uprooted by mere stringent enforcement alone.

"Incessant demand from the public will sustain the illicit trade, thereby nullifying the enforcement efforts and bringing irrevocable damage to Hong Kong's economy and reputation," he explained.

The long-term solution, therefore, rested with education in changing people's mentality, and in raising respect for intellectual property, he concluded.
19990904_007.e:
HK Customs praised for its good work

The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, today (Saturday) praised the Hong Kong Customs for its good work, which had contributed greatly to the society.

Mr Tung said this when inspecting the Customs and Excise Department's Departmental Review to mark its 90th Anniversary at the Customs and Excise Training School in Tuen Mun.

He noted that the Department had taken vigorous actions against rights infringement activities and had established close links with mainland land international law enforcement authorities as well as the relevant authorities to protect intellectual property rights.

"The Department's success in law enforcement has helped upholding the law and order of Hong Kong.

The fine balance that it has maintained between law enforcement and trade facilitation has enhanced our competitiveness and strengthened our position as one of the finest commercial centres in the world," Mr Tung said.

More importantly, he noted that the Department had proven to the world through its unrelenting boundary control and active participation in the international customs arena that Hong Kong remained a separate customs territory after its return to China, and that the concept of "one country, two systems" had been implemented successfully in Hong Kong.

"With the approach of the 21st Century, we commit ourselves to developing Hong Kong into a centre of innovation and technology," Mr Tung went on.

To achieve this goal, he pointed out that the Customs and Excise Department shall continue to play an important role in the protection of intellectual property rights.

The history of the Customs and Excise Department can be traced back to its predecessor, the Preventive Service, which was set up in 1909 with a small establishment of 26 Revenue Officers.

Over the past nine decades, Hong Kong has transformed from a seaport into a leading international commercial centre.

The Department has also undergone considerable expansion in both its establishment and scope of responsibilities.

With an establishment of 5,200 strong staff members, the Customs and Excise Department is now a major Department under the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, committed to the enforcement of 48 different pieces of legislation.

Taking part in today's Departmental Review were 257 Customs officers from various Commands of the Department.

Photo: The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, inspecting the Customs and Excise Department's 90th Anniversary Departmental review at the Department's Training School in Tuen Mun
19990126_010.e:
Significant contributions by HK Customs

The Customs and Excise Department contributes significantly to law and order and the economic well-being of Hong Kong.

This was said today (Tuesday) by the President of the Legislative Council, Mrs Rita Fan, when addressing the 1999 International Customs Day launched by the Hong Kong Customs.

"The Department detects and prevents illegal movements of goods into or out of Hong Kong, and protects and collects revenue on dutiable commodities," Mrs Fan noted.

In addition, the Hong Kong Customs provided efficient import and export clearance services to legitimate trade, suppressed narcotics trafficking and drug abuses, enforced protection on intellectual property rights, consumer interests in product safety, weights and measures and other trading standards, she added.

"I am impressed with the professionalism and dedication of officers of the Hong Kong Customs in performing these duties," she said.

Mrs Fan noted that the celebration of the International Customs Day was held in Hong Kong because Hong Kong was a staunch supporter of the World Customs Organisation (WCO), and Hong Kong Customs actively took part in international customs activities and supported international customs co-operation.

In recognition of Hong Kong Customs' contributions, the WCO elected Hong Kong a member of of its Policy Commissioner for two years in July 1998.

The 1999 International Customs Day is the second remarkable event launched by the Hong Kong Customs since Hong Kong became a Special Administrative Region of China.

Hong Kong became a full member of the WCO in 1987 and this is the 12th year it has celebrated the International Customs Day.

The annual event is a means of promoting Customs co-operation and forging closer links among Customs officials of different Customs Administrations.

More than 300 guests, including members of the Executive and Legislative Councils, senior government officials, counsels-general and foreign Customs attaches, and top executives from trade and business organisations, attended today's reception at the Customs and Excise Service Senior Officers' Mess.
19980117_001.e:
HK plays active role in protecting intellectual property rights 

As an important financial and trading centre in the world, Hong Kong has been playing an active role in the protection of intellectual property.

The Chief Executive, Mr TUNG Chee Hwa, said this today (Saturday) at the passing-out parade of the Customs and Excise Training School.

Mr Tung noted that after the establishment of the Special Administrative Region, Hong Kong continued to function effectively as a separate customs territory under the existing trading systems and committed itself to the successful implementation of the "one country, two systems" concept.

"The Customs and Excise Department undertakes a wide range of responsibilities, including revenue collection, anti-narcotics and anti-smuggling work, protection of intellectual property rights and consumer interests, trade facilitation as well as trade controls," he said.

The Department, which is also responsible for all operation for the detection of pirated and counterfeit goods, works closely with overseas law-enforcers as well as trademark and copyright owners in its fight against acts of infringement.

"The service of the Department in recent years has been outstanding particularly in the area of protection of copyright and trademarks," he noted.

Mr Tung told the officers at the parade that he was confident that they would continue to step up their action in combating piracy and counterfeiting for the protection of intellectual property rights.

"I am also pleased to note that your Department is in process of modernisation in areas such as information technology and human resources management.

New computer systems are being installed.

Equipment has been upgraded for greater safety and better duty performance," Mr Tung said.

He noted that arrangements have also been made for the building of new customs launches and that Customs Headquarters building was on the drawing board.

"All these point to the fact that the Department is a progressive and forward-looking organisation, moving forward into a new era and will continue to play an important role in the Special Administrative Region," Mr Tung concluded.

Thirty-one probationary inspectors and 106 probationary Customs officers took part in the parade today.
19990904_008.e:
Chief Executive's speech at Anniversary of Customs and Excise Department

Following is the full text of the speech by the Chief Executive of the HKSAR, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, at the Departmental Review in celebration of the 90th Anniversary of the Customs and Excise Department today (Saturday):

Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, officers on parade,

It gives me great pleasure to take part in today's Departmental Review, which marks the 90th Anniversary of the Customs and Excise Department.

The smart turnout and dignified bearing of the officers on parade just now have not only reflected their own merit as a group of well-trained disciplinary officers, but also brought great pride and honour to the Department as a whole.

The history of the Customs and Excise Department can be traced back to its predecessor, the Preventive Service, which was set up in 1909 with a small establishment of 26 Revenue Officers.

Over the past nine decades, Hong Kong has transformed from a petty seaport into a leading international commercial centre.

The Department has also undergone considerable expansion in both its establishment and scope of responsibilities.

With an establishment of 5,200 strong staff members, the Customs and Excise Department is now a major department under the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, committed to the enforcement of 48 different pieces of legislation.

Despite the ever-increasing workload over the years, the Customs and Excise Department has made outstanding achievements in the discharge of its multifaceted duties, including the protection of revenue on dutiable commodities, the detection of drug trafficking and smuggling, the protection of intellectual property rights and consumer interests, the exercise of import and export controls as well as customs clearance of travellers and goods.

Without the concerted efforts of all members of the Department, its past achievements would not have been possible.

The good work of the Customs and Excise Department has in fact contributed greatly to our society.

The Department's success in law enforcement has helped upholding the law and order of Hong Kong.

More importantly, the Department has proven to the world through its unrelenting boundary control, active participation in the international customs arena and sustained efforts to maintain its independence and autonomy in the control of strategic commodities that Hong Kong remains a separate customs territory after its return to China, and that the concept of "one country, two systems" has been implemented successfully in Hong Kong.

With the advent of the 21st Century, we commit ourselves to developing Hong Kong into a centre of innovation and technology.

To achieve this goal, the Customs and Excise Development shall continue to play an important role in the protection of intellectual property rights.

Full utilisation of high-tech products and respect for intellectual property rights are both essential to the social and economic development of Hong Kong as a whole.

To protect intellectual property rights, the Customs and Excise Department has taken vigorous actions against rights infringement activities and has established close links with mainland and international law enforcement authorities as well as the relevant industries.

The Customs and Excise Department has secured high regard for its effectiveness and efficiency locally as well as in the mainland and throughout the world.

On the auspicious occasion of its 90th Anniversary, I am pleased to extend to the Department my sincere congratulations and take great pride in all the past achievements it has made.

As we move towards the 21st Century, I believe that the Department will carry forward its good tradition and continue its endeavours to provide the community with highly efficient service and contribute to the stability and prosperity of Hong Kong.

I have full confidence that with the joint efforts of all its staff members, the Department will remain highly responsive to the changing environment with sustained determination to stand challenges and achieve higher goals through self-improvement.

Thank you very much.
19990302_020.e:
Expansion of Customs responsibility

The scope of responsibility of the Customs and Excise Department has greatly expanded in the last two years, in particular in the fight against copyright piracy.

Equally notably were the checking of illegal transshipment of textiles and garments and enforcing product safety standards.

This was stated today (Tuesday) by the Commissioner of Customs and Excise, Mr Lawrence Li Shu-fai, when addressing a farewell parade at the Customs and Excise Training School.

More than 300 customs officers from various commands took part in the parade to bid farewell to Mr Li, who will be retiring this month.

"Our establishment has also expanded from 4,273 in 1997 to today's 5,196 to cope with our work which has increased both in volume and in complexity," said Mr Li.

He told the officers in the parade that they were a professional and conscientious workforce that contributed to the stability and economic well being of Hong Kong.

He also outlined significant progress of the department in the last two years.

This included the relocation from Kai Tak to the New Airport at Chek Lap Kok, the development of a new air cargo clearance system to enhance their efficiency and to improve their customer service and the operation at the River Trade Terminal to provide customs clearance service for cargo imported by river trade vessels.

"We laid the foundation stone for the Kwai Chung Customhouse scheduled for completion next year.

We started publishing an in-house news bulletin.

We formed a Retired Officers' Association.

"We are at an advanced stage of establishing an education fund for our children, which is expected to be finalised before the end of this year," he said.

He pointed out that other examples of the progress included the establishment of a marine base at Stonecutters Island, the expansion of Narcotics Dog Unit and the purchase of six new customs launches and two mobile x-ray examination systems for containers.

"I feel happy to have spent my entire career with the Customs and Excise Department in which I have served for 35 years and of which I was the Commissioner since 1996," he noted.

Mr Li, in conclusion, stressed that he was confident that professionalism and enthusiasm displayed by the officers would ensure that the department continued to develop.

19990127_030.e:
LQ14: Charitable institutions under IRD

Following is a question by the Hon Christine LOH Kung-wai and a written reply by the Secretary for the Treasury, Miss Denise Yue, in the Legislative Council today (Wednesday):

Question :

I have received reports that a number of social organisations had their charitable body status removed by the Administration.

In this connection, will the Administration inform this Council :

(a) whether it has changed the qualifying criteria for charitable bodies;

(b) which and how government bureaux and departments are involved in the assessment of charitable bodies;

(c) of those organisations that had their charitable body status removed in the last two years and the basis for removing such status;

(d) of the number of charitable bodies currently being reassessed for their status; and

(e) whether it has assessed how the reassessment will benefit the Administration and the community ?

Reply :

Section 88 of the Inland Revenue Ordinance (IRO) (Cap. 112) provides tax exemption for charitable institutions.

The term "charitable institution" is however not separately defined in the IRO.

In considering whether an organisation can be accepted as a charitable institution for tax exemption purposes under the Ordinance, the Inland Revenue Department (IRD) has applied the meaning given to the term in English case law.

Based on an authoritative court decision, purposes that may be accepted as charitable can be categorised as follows -

(i) relief of poverty;

(ii) advancement of education;

(iii) advancement of religion; and

(iv) other purposes of a charitable nature beneficial to the community not falling under any of the preceding categories.

IRD has all along adopted the above criteria in determining whether an organisation can be accepted as a charitable institution for tax exemption purposes.

With regard to part (a) of the question, we have not changed the criteria for recognising charitable institutions under section 88 of the IRO recently.

However, since 1990 we have not been granting tax exemption status to overseas charities unless the charities concerned establish themselves in Hong Kong.

We are presently reviewing the tax exemption status previously granted to overseas charities and will withdraw the exemption if the charities are not established in Hong Kong.

With regard to part (b) of the question, IRD is responsible for recognising charitable institutions or trusts for the purpose of granting exemption under the IRO.

The Department will examine, among other things, the governing instrument of the organisation concerned.

In particular, it will scrutinise the object clause, income clause and dissolution clause to ensure that all the objects of the organisation are charitable and that there are adequate safeguards to prevent the channelling of funds for non-charitable purposes.

To confirm that the objects of organisations are still charitable and their activities are compatible with their objects, the Department will review the recognised charitable organisations in cycles of approximately four years.

With regard to part (c) of the question, during the financial years 1996-97 and 1997-98, tax exemption was withdrawn in 117 cases.

Any removal of names from the list of approved charities due to the withdrawal of tax exemption granted is published in the Government Gazette at quarterly intervals.

An updated list of all approved charities is gazetted annually.

Tax exemption will be withdrawn under various circumstances including -

(i) the organisation has not replied to the IRD's enquiries arising from the periodic review;

(ii) the organisation is carrying out an act which is not authorised by its governing instrument;

(iii) the organisation has ceased its activities or is dormant; or

(iv) the organisation has been dissolved or wound up.

With regard to part (d) of the question, as of now, IRD is reassessing the status of 134 charitable organisations.

With regard to part (e) of the question, it is necessary to review the charities periodically so as to ensure that only those entities recognised as charitable organisations under the IRO should be granted tax exemption.

Where it is considered that a recognised institution can no longer be regarded as a charitable institution for purposes of the IRO, the tax exemption previously granted will be withdrawn.

Upon the withdrawal of tax exemption, the organisation concerned will be subject to the provisions of the IRO in respect of its tax liability, if any.
