19990819_009.e:
Seizure of Heroin by Customs

Customs officers yesterday (Wednesday) smashed a packaging and distribution heroin centre following the seizure of 450 grams of no. 4 heroin, worth about $160,000, and the arrest of two brothers in Sha Tin.

After intensive investigations, officers from Customs Drug Investigation Bureau yesterday evening laid an ambush outside a residential building in Sha Tin Main Street.

About 10 pm, the officers intercepted two men while they were leaving the building.

Upon search, about 165 grams of suspected no. 4 heroin were seized.

The officers later gained entry into a premises in the same building where another 285 grams of suspected no. 4 heroin and some packaging apparatus were seized.

The seized drugs are believed for distribution in Kowloon areas.

The arrested men, aged 20 and 21, will be charged with "Trafficking in a Dangerous Drug" and will appear in Sha Tin Magistracy tomorrow.

Any person who is found guilty of the offence shall be liable to a maximum fine of $5 million and life imprisonment.
19990330_028.e:
Seizure of High Graded Heroin at Airport

Airport Customs officers yesterday (Monday) seized 7.5 kilograms of No. 4 heroin, worth $7.5 million, from two women from an incoming flight from Bangkok.

Shortly after 1 pm yesterday, the two women, both local residents, approached the Customs counter for clearance upon their arrival.

Their bulky and thick clothing, however, raised the suspicion of the Customs officers.

Upon subsequent personal search, the drugs, being packed into a number of packets strapped around the bodies, thigh and inside their shoes, were uncovered.

The arrested, aged 28 and 34, will appear at Tsuen Wan Magistracy tomorrow, to face charge of "trafficking in a dangerous drug" under the Dangerous Drugs Ordinance.

Customs officers have so far this year effected 10 drug trafficking cases at the airport.

A total of 20.8 kilograms of heroin, 8.2 kilograms of cannabis resin and 1.1 kilograms of cocaine were seized.

A total of 13 suspects, including seven Chinese men, two Chinese women and four foreigners, were arrested.

In most of the cases, the drugs were concealed by body-packed method, and uncovered after personal search.

Trafficking in a dangerous drug is a serious offence.

The maximum penalty is life imprisonment.
19991217_003.e:
Drug manufacturing centre neutralised

Police believed that a drug manufacturing centre has been neutralised following the arrest of a 39-year-old man and the seizure of $16 million of suspected No.4 heroin by officers attached to the Narcotics Bureau (NB) yesterday (Thursday).

Speaking at a press briefing this (Friday) afternoon, Chief Superintendent of Narcotics Bureau , Mr Koo Sii-hong, said following extensive investigation into a drug syndicate, NB officers laid an ambush outside a carpark at Lung Fung Garden in Sheung Shui yesterday afternoon.

"Police officers intercepted a private car at about 3.30 pm and seized about 14.7 kilograms of suspected No.4 heroin inside the boot.

The 39-year-old driver on board was arrested," he said.

"Subsequent search in a flat on Luk Ming Street in To Kwa Wan led to the seizure of another 200 grams of suspected No.4 heroin and a quantity of drug manufacturing equipment including hydraulic jacks as well as chemical for drug dilution."

"The haul, with a total weight of 15 kilograms, could fetch about $16 million in the retail market," he added.

Initial enquiries revealed that the drug manufacturing centre was linked to a drug syndicate neutralised by NB officers early this month during which $3.76 million worth of heroin and two genuine pistols were seized.

The man is still being detained for enquiries.

Mr Koo said that there was an increase in the amount of heroin seized in Hong Kong from 209 kilograms last year to 300 kilograms so far this year.

He explained that the rise was not due to an increase in the demand for drugs in the market.

"According to the Central Registry for Drug Abuse Records, the number of people abusing drugs had decreased from 14 281 people in the first nine months last year to 13 704 the same period this year," he said.

He attributed the increase in drug seizure to the good strategy and intelligence work of Police.

Mr Koo also took the opportunity to warn that anyone convicted of trafficking in heroin of over one kilogram will be liable to 20 years in jail on conviction.

Police Report No.7

Issued by PPRB
19991222_007.e:
Seizure of No. 4 heroin by Customs

A 21-year-old man, arrested by Customs in connection with the seizure of $7 million worth of No. 4 heroin in Kwun Tong this (Wednesday) morning, will appear at Kwun Tong Magistracy tomorrow to face "Trafficking in Dangerous Drug" charge.

Following prolonged investigation, officers from Customs Drug Investigation Bureau mounted an anti-narcotics operation in the vicinity of a public carpark at the junction of Shun On Road and Shun Lee Tsuen Road, Kwun Tong at about 6:30 am today.

The officers swang into action when seeing their target, a 21-year-old man, acting suspiciously near a private car.

The suspect was arrested when trying to unload 15 slabs of No. 4 heroin, weighing 7 kilograms, from the boot of the vehicle.

"Enquiries revealed that the dangerous drugs were for distribution in Kowloon area," a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department said.

The maximum penalty for the offence of "Trafficking in a dangerous drugs" is a fine of $5 million and life imprisonment, the spokesman warned.
19991020_018.e:
Heroin manufacturing centre smashed

Customs officers yesterday (Tuesday) smashed a heroin manufacturing centre and arrested two men and two women in Tuen Mun and Fotan districts following the seizure of 2.41 kilograms of no. 4 heroin, worth about $1.5 million.

At about 2:30 pm yesterday, officers of Customs Drug Investigation Bureau intercepted a man outside a private carpark in Fotan.

As a result, 1,785 grams of suspected No.4 heroin were found in his possession.

Customs officers later searched a domestic unit nearby and found another 375 grams of No.4 heroin.

Another man and two women inside the premises were also arrested.

Further enquiries led to the seizure of another 250 grams of No. 4 heroin and a set of heroin manufacturing apparatus inside a domestic flat in Tuen Mun.

Seized from the arrestees were also cash $100,000 and gold ornament and jewellery valued at $400,000.

The arrested, aged from 20 to 32, will later be charged with "Trafficking in a Dangerous Drug" and "Manufacturing a Dangerous Drug" under the Dangerous Drugs Ordinance.

"We believe that this drug syndicate has been operating for about half a year and the drugs were mainly distributed to West Kowloon areas," a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department said.

Last year, Customs officers neutralised 13 drug manufacturing and distribution centres with the seizure of 26 kilograms of No. 4 heroin and the arrest of 17 people.

The officers had so far this year smashed 15 similar centres with the seizure of 26.3 kilograms of No.4 heroin and the arrest of 45 suspects, the spokesman added.
19990106_046.e:
Seizure of No.4 Heroin at Airport

Watchfulness on the part of Customs officers led to the seizure of 6.1 kilograms of No. 4 heroin worth $6.1 million at the Airport yesterday (Tuesday).

Two men, aged 22 and 37, who were about to depart for Taiwan, were arrested in connection with the seizure.

Acting on intelligence, Customs officers of the Airport Investigation Division and Customs Drug Investigation Bureau yesterday morning conducted an anti-narcotics operation to process outgoing passengers at the departure level of the Airport.

During the operation, two Hong Kong residents, who were about to depart for Taiwan by an international flight, were intercepted for search.

As a result, each of them was found body-packed with 2.9 kilograms and 3.2 kilograms of high grade heroin respectively.

Customs officers conducted search of two residential premises at Tsuen Wan and Sha Tau Kok but no further seizure was made.

"This is the first major drug seizure made by Customs officers at the Airport this year," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department.

Investigation into the case was still ongoing in order to track down other syndicate members, the spokesman added.

The two arrested will be separately charged with trafficking in a dangerous drug.

They will appear at Tsuen Wan Magistracy later today.
20000428_029.e:
Seizure of heroin by Customs

A 44-year-old man arrested by Customs Drug Investigation Bureau will appear in Kwun Tong Magistracy this (April 28) afternoon, charged with trafficking in a dangerous drug and manufacturing a dangerous drug.

The suspect was arrested by the officers yesterday in Lam Tin following the seizure of 820 grams of No. 4 heroin worth about $500,000.

Shortly before 7 pm, officers of Customs Drug Investigation Bureau intercepted a man at Ping Tin Estate.

As a result, 120 grams of No. 4 heroin were reportedly found in his possession.

A subsequent search of the residence of the suspect resulted in the further seizure of 700 grams of No. 4 heroin and a set of heroin manufacturing apparatus.

"We believe that this drug syndicate has been operated for about a month and the drugs seized were mainly for distribution in East Kowloon area," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department.
20000114_011.e:
Seizure of Dangerous Drugs by Customs

Officers of the Customs Drug Investigation Bureau, in an anti-narcotics operation, arrested a 45-year-old man and seized 728 grams of suspected No. 4 heroin, worth about $700,000, in Wong Tai Sin today (Friday).

At about 8.20 am today, the officers intercepted the man outside Wong Tai Sin MTR Station and found the dangerous drugs in his possession.

"We believe the dangerous drugs are for distribution in Kowloon area," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department.

The arrested man will appear in Kwun Tong Magistracy tomorrow to face a charge of "trafficking in a dangerous drug".

The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $5 million and life imprisonment.
19980515_018.e:
Seizure of No. 4 heroin by Customs

Customs officers today (Friday) seized 360 grams of high grade No. 4 heroin, worth about $300,000, from an incoming passenger at Lo Wu Control Point.

At about 9.30 am, a Hong Kong resident was intercepted by Customs officers for examination.

One slab of high grade No. 4 heroin weighing 360 grams was found strapped on his waist.

He was later brought to his residence in Sham Shui Po for a search but no further contraband was discovered.

The 49-year-old man will appear at Fanling Magistracy tomorrow to face charge of "Trafficking in a Dangerous Drug" under the Dangerous Drugs Ordinance.

Customs will continue to step up enforcement action to stem cross-border drug trafficking activity.
20000320_005.e:
Seizure of high-grade heroin by Customs

Officers of the Customs Drug Investigation Bureau, in an anti-narcotics operation, arrested a man and seized 350 grams of No. 4 high-grade heroin, worth about $150,000, in Fanling today (March 20).

At about 9.30 am today, the officers intercepted a goods vehicle at the road side of San Wan Road, Fanling.

Upon search, Customs officers found a slab of high grade No.4 heroin weighing 350 gram underneath the driver's seat.

The driver, a 21-year-old man, was arrested.

The arrested man will appear in Fanling Magistracy tomorrow to face a charge of "trafficking in a dangerous drug" under the Dangerous Drugs Ordinance.

The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $5 million and life imprisonment.

19981214_012.e:
Control measures on avian flu effective

No new cases of influenza A H5N1 had occurred in Hong Kong for almost a year.

This shows that control and preventive measures taken by the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government (HKSARG) in containing the disease have been effective.

The conclusion is supported by influenza experts of the World Health Organisation (WHO) and the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in Atlanta, USA and other world health experts.

In a proclamation made recently by world health experts and scientists on influenza from a number of countries, they applauded the vigorous and carefully considered action taken by the Hong Kong Government against the avian virus outbreak a year ago, saying that the action might have saved the world from an influenza pandemic.

In reviewing the situation in Hong Kong, Deputy Director of Health, HKSARG, and Chairman of the Inter-Departmental Co-ordinating Committee on Avian Flu, Dr Paul Saw said today (Monday): "The absence of new human cases of avian flu in almost a year is most encouraging, but we must not be complacent."

"This is necessary as influenza viruses are endemic in this part of the world and they have the ability to mutate."

"The public should remain vigilant and maintain good health and strong immunity against the disease while surveillance for influenza in human and in poultry should be maintained and international collaboration intensified."

Dr Saw pointed out that the avian flu virus could have spread and caused an influenza pandemic if decisive and vigorous actions had not been taken in Hong Kong.

Actions taken in Hong Kong in the past year had gained time for scientists to find out more about the virus.

"According to available evidence, it has been clearly established that the primary mode of transmission is a direct one from birds to humans," he said.

"Out of the 1 366 poultry samples collected in markets just before the mass chicken slaughter, nearly 19 per cent of samples from chickens and about 2 per cent from ducks were found to contain the virus."

Results of studies available so far confirmed that the primary mode of transmission of H5N1 infection is from poultry to man, most likely through contact with the faeces of poultry.

Cohort studies showed that transmission of the virus from person-to-person had occurred but was uncommon and inefficient.

There is no evidence that H5N1 infection is transmitted to man from raw, chilled or frozen poultry foods.

On measures taken to contain the outbreak and to monitor the situation, Dr Saw said a whole host of measures had been taken in Hong Kong with the joint efforts of a number of government departments, the Hospital Authority and academics from the universities.

The Department of Health's (DH) surveillance for influenza, which picked up the first index case in the world last year, had been extended to all public hospitals, all 63 general out-patients clinics and 29 general practitioners since December last year.

In the past year, some 18 000 specimens had been received and tested for influenza A. 

None of them, except those taken from case patients, were positive for H5N1.

This enhanced surveillance system played a major part in monitoring the situation and would trigger off action where necessary.

On the curative side, the Hospital Authority had devoted great efforts in providing quality medical care to each patient during the outbreak.

Three centres were designated to provide rapid diagnosis for influenza A for all public hospitals with preliminary results reported within 24 hours.

The mass chicken slaughter launched by the HKSARG between December 29 and 31, 1997 proved to be very effective in eradicating the virus.

The latest date of onset for a human case of avian flu was December 28, 1997, one day before the mass chicken slaughter was launched.

To ensure a safe supply of poultry upon restocking, stringent controls on import of chicken and other poultry had been introduced by the Agriculture and Fisheries Department (AFD) prior to and after the resumption of import of these poultry into the territory.

This had so far been working smoothly.

Over 200 000 blood samples have been examined.

No evidence of active infection with avian influenza had been detected in any consignment of imported poultry.

On the local front, on-farm testing of birds was introduced for poultry on farms, along with new licensing conditions covering hygiene and management practices.

All flocks are serologically tested during the growing period.

All farms had remained free from infection with H5 influenza so far.

To prevent H5N1 virus being passed on from waterfowl, a potential carrier, to chicken, the policy of segregation of waterfowl from other poultry was introduced in May this year at all levels from import to retail with the support and co-operation of the traders.

All these, together with surveillance on birds and markets conducted by the AFD, had safeguarded the health of poultry and ensured the disease did not occur.

Great emphasis had also been placed in upgrading the hygiene standard of markets at both wholesale and retail level.

Additional requirements and conditions had been imposed by the two municipal services departments on the licensed fresh provision shops and market stalls selling poultry.

These included requirements to use plastic or metal poultry cages instead of wooden cages, provision of refrigerator or chiller for keeping poultry carcasses, water heaters and high pressure water jet cleaner for daily cleansing etc.

Dr Saw pointed out that the overall hygiene standard of poultry retail outlets is now much improved.

Enhancement of hygiene standard is on-going and the poultry retail outlets are subject to regular inspections by the health inspectors.

On the education and publicity front, to enlist the public to combat the avian flu, guidelines for influenza prevention were prepared for doctors, health care workers, schools teachers, staff of child care service units, rehabilitation service units and elderly centres.

People handling poultry and animal waste were advised on personal hygiene and ways to prevent contact with poultry faecal matter.

These were backed up by general publicity on TV, radio and the printed media.

In addition, Dr Saw pointed out that the Hong Kong SAR Government had launched a "Healthy Living into the 21st Century Campaign" which aimed at improving the standards of environmental, food and personal hygiene.

The Campaign will last for three years.

Looking ahead, Dr Saw said the Inter-Departmental Co-ordinating Committee had recommended and the Administration had agreed that:

* International collaboration in the monitoring and prevention of influenza, involving various specialties and disciplines, should continue.

* In Hong Kong, the surveillance for influenza in human population should be continued.

* The influenza surveillance in animals, in particular poultry, should be maintained.

* The present system of control measures to ensure safe supply of poultry should be maintained.

Dr Saw concluded that the whole avian flu crisis demonstrated the importance of disease surveillance and control with international collaboration.
19971207_001.e:
Updates on H5N1 influenza A situation 

The preliminary investigations showed that at this stage, human-to-human transmission of the H5N1 influenza A virus has not been proven and further investigations will be made to study this possibility, the Special Working Group on H5N1 announced today (Sunday).

The initial findings also showed that the four H5 cases did not share a common source, nor was the virus transmitted from one case to the others.

Speaking at a press conference convened after an urgent meeting earlier this afternoon, the Deputy Director of Health, Dr Paul Saw, who is the Chairman of the working group, said: "The first case was confirmed in August.

Since then, we have stepped up surveillance and as a result, we have been able to detect the latest three cases.

"This latest development has caused concern both in the local and the international communities.

However, there is no cause for panic as available evidence does not suggest that the disease is widespread."

Dr Saw said since the detection of the first case in August, Hong Kong had been working closely with the World Health Organisation (WHO) and the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention and other national authorities in surveillance, case detection and investigation of this new strain of influenza A virus.

"The WHO has been asked to alert vaccine production centres in the world in the case investigation to follow developments here with a view to preparing the necessary vaccines," he said.

"Arising from these suspected cases, the Department of Health has stepped up the influenza surveillance activities in Hong Kong and the WHO fully supports the measures being taken."

To further enhance surveillance in Hong Kong, Dr Saw said, the Department of Health would extend surveillance coverage to all General Out-patient Clinics.

The Hospital Authority would also set up surveillance in public hospitals.

In the meantime, Dr Saw said, the Agriculture and Fisheries Department had also increased surveillance in poultry in collaboration with The University of Hong Kong.

He said the Department would disseminate to doctors, medical professionals, colleges and health care workers available information about the H5 virus through letters and the Department of Health's homepage on the Internet (http:/www.info.gov.hk/dh/).

The special working group also released the details of the two suspected case discovered yesterday.

The 54-year-old man involved was admitted to the Queen Elizabeth Hospital on November 29 and died on December 5 of complications arising from pneumonia.

The 13-year-old girl was admitted on November 26 and is now under treatment in Prince of Wales Hospital.

Investigations into the two suspected cases are still continuing.

Dr Saw advised members of the public that the best way to combat influenza infection was to build up body resistance by having a proper diet with adequate exercise and rest.

"Good ventilation should be maintained to avoid the spread of respiratory tract infection.

"As for the young, the elderly and those with chronic diseases, they should seek medical consultations promptly if they develop influenza-like illness," Dr Saw added.
19990803_013.e:
Influenza A H9N2 poses no imminent major threat to public health

Investigation of the two cases of influenza A H9N2, that occurred in Hong Kong in March this year suggests that this type of avian flu virus causes relatively mild illness in humans and poses no imminent major threat to public health.

This finding was based on the clinical conditions of the two cases in Hong Kong and preliminary serology studies using blood samples collected from patient contacts, from blood donors and from poultry workers.

These studies were conducted jointly by the Department of Health (DH) of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region and the US Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in Atlanta.

Speaking at a press conference today (Tuesday), DH's Consultant (Community Medicine), Dr Mak Kwok-hang said the results from the investigation of H9N2 suggested that the main mode of transmission was from birds to humans while the possibility of human-to-human transmission remains open.

On the serological study, he pointed out that there was a low prevalence of antibody to the H9N2 viruses isolated from the patients among people screened in contact tracing of patients(0.4 percent), blood donors (0.5 percent) and poultry workers (2 percent) tested.

At the same time, serology tests conducted by the Agriculture and Fisheries Department indicated that a high proportion of poultry in Hong Kong markets had been exposed to H9 virus.

However, it was noted that the virus usually causes mild symptoms, if any, among birds and poultry and there had been no new cases of influenza caused by H9 virus in humans in Hong Kong.

These, together with the satisfactory outcome and full recovery of the two girls, indicated that the transmission of the isolated H9N2 virus among human is relatively rare and inefficient.

Hence, the Special Investigation Group comprising of local and overseas medical and veterinary experts and scientists concluded at the present stage that the discovery of H9N2 virus in humans does not appear to pose an imminent major threat to public health.

On poultry workers, Dr Mak commented that test results available so far and other studies being undertaken in other countries suggested that poultry workers may have a higher level of exposure to H9 virus than the general population but this was not unexpected given their close association with poultry on a daily basis.

He stressed that this was no cause for undue alarm as there have been no reported cases of illness caused by avian influenza viruses in this group.

He advised those handling poultry to continue to observe good personal hygiene practices in their daily work.

The Special Investigation Group also noted that sequencing of genes from H9N2 viruses isolated from the patients demonstrate that all genes of these two viruses are avian in nature, providing no evidence for reassortment with human influenza virus genes.

The Government accepted the Group's recommendation that the enhanced surveillance for poultry and human infections be continued, noting that this is one of the best measures to combat influenza.

To prevent influenza A H9N2, the public are advised:-

* to improve ventilation;

* build up their body resistance through proper diet;

* take adequate rest;

* maintain regular exercise;

* observe good personal, food and environmental hygiene; and

* wash hands thoroughly after they come into contact or handle poultry or bird faeces.

At the same time, the municipal services departments and the Agriculture and Fisheries Department would continue to undertake the necessary measures to maintain proper hygiene in markets.

Apart from the first two cases of influenza A H9N2 that occurred in Hong Kong in March this year and subsequently confirmed in April, Hong Kong had not seen any new cases of this type of avian flu in the last few months.

Both patients, a 1-year-old girl and a 4-year-old girl, had recovered fully and uneventfully.
19991019_016.e:
Influenza being closely monitored

As part of its influenza surveillance programme, the Department of Health (DH) was closely following up on the isolation of an influenza virus sample from patient which suggested association with swine origin.

DH's Consultant on Community Medicine, Dr Mak Kwok-hang (today) said that the sample was being tested separately at reference laboratories in the United States and the United Kingdom.

Confirmation of result was pending.

He said that the sample of virus, preliminarily identified in Hong Kong as an atypical influenza A H3N2 strain, was isolated from a 10-month old girl who was treated at Tuen Mun Hospital for fever and influenza like illness last month.

The girl had fully recovered uneventfully and had been discharged from hospital earlier.

There was, so far, no evidence of secondary spread.

Dr Mak pointed out that the swine strain of influenza A H3N2 virus had been reported as a common agent of respiratory infection affecting swine population.

Sporadic human infections caused by this swine flu H3N2 had been reported in Europe before.

However, overseas experience suggested that the patients made full recoveries without complication and there was no evidence that this swine flu could cause outbreaks in human population.

Hence, there was no cause for undue alarm at this stage.

If confirmed, this is the first time that the swine flu H3N2 virus was isolated from patient in Hong Kong.

Dr Mak added that this incident reflected the importance to maintain vigilance in influenza surveillance.

The efforts would be continued in Hong Kong.

To prevent influenza, members of the public are advised:

* to build up a good body immunity by having a proper diet, adequate exercise and rest;

* to maintain good ventilation to avoid the spread of germs;

* to avoid visiting crowded places with poor ventilation;

* to observe good personal hygiene;

* the young, elderly and those with chronic diseases should consult doctors promptly if they develop influenza-like symptoms.
19990127_024.e:
Influenza surveillance

Following is a question by the Hon Lau Kong-wah and an oral reply by the Secretary for Health and Welfare, Mrs Katherine Fok, in the Legislative Council today(Wednesday):

Question:

It is reported that Type A Influenza H3N2 virus is spreading rampantly in the northeast of the Mainland and it is forecast that the relevant influenza cases will spread to Hong Kong during the Lunar New Year period.

In this connection, will the Government inform this Council:

(a) of the mechanism currently in place for the authorities to monitor the influenza cases, and of the public and private medical institutions involved in the monitoring mechanism; 

how this monitoring mechanism compares to the one set up during the peak period of avian influenza infection for monitoring such cases; 

and whether it plans to set up a task force to monitor the spreading of this strain of influenza virus;

(b) of the effect of this strain of influenza virus on the human body, and of the specific measures that the Administration will adopt to prevent relevant diseases from spreading in Hong Kong; and

(c) whether it will consider stepping up its publicity efforts to advise members of the public on how to avoid being infected; 

if so, the details of that?

Answer:

Madam President,

(a) Since 1962, a surveillance system on influenza has been set up in Hong Kong to monitor the trend of spread of different types of influenza.

At present, the sentinel surveillance system for influenza comprises 63 government out-patient clinics and 28 private medical practitioners.

They report to the Department of Health on a weekly basis the number of patients that have influenza or influenza-like illness.

When compared to the surveillance system in operation during the peak period of avian influenza infection, the number of government out-patient clinics currently involved in the sentinel surveillance system for influenza remains the same but there are now 10 more private medical practitioners having joined the scheme.

The Hospital Authority set up a Taskforce in December 1997 for monitoring avian influenza.

The Taskforce has now broadened its monitoring scope to cover all types of influenza.

The Hospital Authority monitors closely the number of inpatients admitted to public hospitals with influenza and their conditions, and maintains a close liaison with the Department of Health on this matter.

In parallel, the Government Virus Unit of the Department of Health carries out laboratory investigations by using clinical specimens collected from patients with influenza to identify and monitor the number and types of prevailing influenza virus.

The existing surveillance system which monitors all types of influenza is functioning satisfactorily.

We have been able to implement preventive measures promptly.

There is no need to set up a special task force to monitor the spread of a particular influenza virus.

(b) The Department of Health has confirmed with the health authorities of Mainland China that the virus recently circulating in the northeast, northwest and northern area of the Mainland is Influenza type A3 (H3N2).

This particular influenza virus, like other influenza viruses, will cause fever, cough and sore throat in the affected persons.

Most patients will recover in a few days, but the elderly and patients with chronic heart and lung diseases may develop complications more easily and should take greater care to look after themselves.

This virus strain was prevalent in Hong Kong in February and March last year.

A lot of people in Hong Kong should have acquired immunity against this virus strain.

According to Department of Health's assessment, it is unlikely that this virus will spread rampantly in Hong Kong.

We will maintain close contacts with the relevant Mainland authorities and make use of the sentinel surveillance system to closely monitor the spread of influenza in Hong Kong.

In Hong Kong, February to March and June to July are usually the peak periods of influenza infection.

The Government will strengthen the publicity on influenza prevention before the peak periods arrive.

Health education information on the prevention of influenza will be disseminated through newspapers, district newspapers and the electronic media.

Members of the public can use the Department of Health's telephone hotline to obtain more information on this subject from our health care staff.

Other publicity measures will include holding district exhibitions and distribution of pamphlets at specific locations, such as travel agencies and immigration checkpoints, to enrich the travellers' knowledge about influenza and enhance their alertness toward the disease.

END/Wednesday, January 27, 1999
19990411_003.e:
Special Investigation Group on Avian Flu recommends close monitoring of situation and more scientific studies

The Special Investigation Group on Avian Flu met today (Sunday) to assess the impact of the discovery of influenza A (H9N2), an avian influenza virus, in humans and to make recommendations on the way forward.

The Group was chaired by the Deputy Director of the Hong Kong Department of Health, Dr Paul Saw and comprised public health doctors, veterinarians as well as both local and overseas experts in microbiology and epidemiology.

The Group commended the prompt detection of the two cases in Hong Kong which reflected the effectiveness of Hong Kong's influenza surveillance system.

It noted the satisfactory outcome and full recovery of the two girls in Hong Kong found to have contracted influenza A (H9N2).

It also noted that the virus is usually causing mild symptoms, if any, among birds and poultry.

The Special Investigation Group initially considered that the discovery of the virus does not appear to pose an imminent major threat to public health.

However, several investigations should be started, in case other H9 human cases appear later and because H9 viruses, similar to other influenza viruses, can change or re-assort and become more easily transmitted.

The situation should therefore be kept under close monitoring and surveillance.

Speaking after the meeting, Dr Keiji Fukuda, Chief of Epidemiology Section of the Influenza Branch of the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in Atlanta said: "The major question about the isolation of influenza A (H9N2) virus in humans is whether they pose a major health risk for people."

To answer this question, Dr Fukuda said the Group should find out

* whether there are other H9N2 infections in people in Hong Kong

* the mode of transmission of the virus to humans

* the risk factors of contracting this virus

* the relation between H9 infection in poultry and in people

To do this, the Special Working Group recommended that several different studies and activities be conducted.

These included:

* most importantly, enhanced influenza surveillance should be continued

* epidemiological studies to identify risk factor and mode of transmission of these viruses

* prevalence studies to find out how common these infections are right now in birds and human

Dr Paul Saw said the Department of Health would co-ordinate actions recommended by the Special Investigation Group.

He said the Group also agreed that chicken and poultry are safe to eat if they are cooked thoroughly.

However, public are reminded again to observe good personal hygiene by washing hands thoroughly after contact with poultry, animals and their excreta.
19971217_010.e:
Control measures of H5N1 virus 

Following is a question by the Hon Lau Kong-wah and a reply by the Secretary for Health and Welfare, Mrs Katherine Fok, in the Provisional Legislative Council today (Wednesday):

Questions:

Since August this year, two cases of influenza A virus H5N1 (commonly knows as the bird influenza) in man were discovered in Hong Kong.

It was also recently announced by the Department of Health that two new cases of suspected infection were found.

Among the four people infected, two were dead.

Such a trend causes worry that the bird influenza might be spreading in the territory.

In this connection, will the Government inform this Council:

(a) whether the Department of Health had immediately taken action to trace the source and identify the causes of the infection following the first person contracting such an illness; if so, what the details are; if not, why not;

(b) of the reasons for the Department of Health announcing the second case only recently, as the infected child had contracted the virus in November;

(c) whether the Department of Health has studied and pursued the development of a new vaccine for preventing and curing the infection by this virus; if so, what the details are; and

(d) of the measures taken by the Department of Health to step up its guidance to the public on the prevention of infection by the bird influenza, before the successful development of a new vaccine?

Reply:

Madam President,

(a) Shortly after the first human case of H5N1 infection was confirmed in August 1997, the Department of Health has been working closely with the World Health Organisation and the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention in the United States to track down the source of infection and the mode of transmission.

The Department of Health has interviewed people who have had close contact with the patients, including their family members, schoolmates, colleagues and the health care staff providing direct care to the patients.

Site visits to the patients' homes, workplace and schools and local animal/poultry farms have also been made.

Specimens including blood samples, throat swabs, etc have been taken and are being investigated in Hong Kong and by the Centres for Diseases Control and Prevention.

We are conducting different studies to determine the mode of transmission.

We hope that the results of these investigations and studies can give us a better understanding of this new virus.

So far, although information has revealed that the virus is avian in nature, we have not reached any definite conclusion on how the virus is transmitted from this source to the human body.

(b) The second case involves a two-year old boy who was admitted into hospital on November 7 with a high fever.

He was discharged two days later.

The specimen taken during his hospital stay by the attending doctor was tested and later found to be positive for the H5 virus on November 25, 1997.

Investigation action by the Department of Health followed immediately and the specimen was sent to the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention for further testing.

A press conference announcing the suspected case and the initial investigation results was held on November 28, 1997.

The case was confirmed by the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention as a H5N1 case on December 13, 1997.

(c) We are maintaining close liaison with the World Health Organisation on the development of vaccine.

The Organisation has alerted the vaccine production centres, requesting them to monitor the H5N1 cases in Hong Kong and make necessary preparations for the production of the vaccine.

Since this is a new virus affecting humans, a detailed understanding of the H5N1 virus including its antigenic structure, mode of transmission etc. must be obtained before a decision can be reached on how to follow up the production of the vaccine.

(d) The Department of Health has been reminding the public that the best protection against influenza is to maintain body immunity by balanced diet, adequate rest, sufficient exercise and the practice of good personal hygiene.

The Department of Health is launching new television and radio announcements to strengthen the above message.

These preventive measures also apply to protection against H5N1 infection.

It is observed from the recent H5N1 cases that the initial symptoms of H5N1 infection are similar to those caused by other types of flu viruses.

Members of the public should seek the doctors' advice as early as possible when they experience flu symptoms.

To ensure accurate diagnosis for treatment, they should not change doctors unnecessarily.

The Department has also issued guidance notes to the doctors giving them information about the virus and on how to handle suspected cases.

To give advice on prevention of H5N1 infection, the Department of Health has set up telephone hotline to handle enquiries from the public.

Leaflets are distributed through relevant departments to the poultry and restaurant workers reminding them of the importance of personal and environmental hygiene.

The Department has also conducted briefings for the Provisional District Board Chairmen and the press to update them on the latest development.

We will continue to maintain and strengthen these public education programmes.
19990407_003.e:
Discovery of first cases of influenza A virus (H9N2) in humans in HK

The Government Virus Unit of the Hong Kong Department of Health (DH) had isolated, in collaboration with local and international health authorities, a new strain of influenza A virus (H9N2) from two patients recently.

"This is the first time H9N2 viruses, an avian influenza virus, are isolated from humans in Hong Kong," Deputy Director of Health, Dr Paul Saw said today (Wednesday).

The two patients are girls aged one and four who recovered fully from influenza-like illnesses last (March) month.

Atypical influenza viruses were picked up from their clinical specimens of throat secretion by the enhanced influenza surveillance system set up to monitor the avian flu situation in Hong Kong since late 1997.

The specimens were sent to World Health Organisation (WHO) Influenza Collaborating Reference Laboratories in United Kingdom and United States for further identification.

Results available today confirmed that the virus was influenza A (H9N2).

The WHO was informed of the finding.

Speaking at a press briefing, Dr Saw said: "This influenza A (H9N2) is an avian influenza virus which has been isolated from duck and chicken for many years."

"Detailed investigations are underway to find out how the patients contracted the viruses."

"At this stage, the two cases appeared isolated.

Notwithstanding this, the Department of Health's special investigation team on avian influenza will work closely with local and overseas experts to assess the global health impact of this new discovery and its mode of transmission."

"This information will be released to the medical professions and the public when available."

Dr Saw said that this virus is sensitive to the drugs amantadine and rimantadine.

He added that Hong Kong has a good medical and health system with adequate resources to provide appropriate treatment for this condition.

With the experience gained in the control of the avian flu outbreak in late 1997, he said that the Department would be better equipped to co-ordinate efforts from international health authorities and local experts to monitor and control the situation.

Members of the public are advised at this stage to observe good ventilation, to have proper diet, exercise and rest to build up body resistance to combat infection.

They are also advised to wash their hands after handling poultry or the birds' excreta.

The public can obtain updated information on influenza from the Department of Health's Homepage (http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/).

They can also get information on the prevention of influenza from the Department's Central Health Education Hotline on Tel No: 2833 0111.
19971216_002.e:
Initial assessment of Influenza A H5N1 cases 

Initial assessment made by the Special Working Group on Influenza A H5N1 noted an association with poultry in some of the cases under investigation, the Director of Health, Dr Margaret Chan said at a press conference today (Tuesday).

She noted that genetic analysis of the H5N1 virus in the first four cases so far had shown avian gene sequences while laboratory results of the other cases were pending.

Information collected during the investigation of the first seven cases - six confirmed and one suspected - indicated that some patients had contacts with poultry before the onset of the disease while others had not.

"This points to the fact that the transmission of the virus both from bird-to-human and human-to-human are possible," Dr Chan said.

"However, the efficiency of transmission from human- to-human should not be high or there should be hundreds and thousands of such cases in the territory by now, according to past experience with other types of influenza.

Thus, the present cluster of cases detected in Hong Kong had not reached epidemic proportions.

"While the mode of transmission requires further study, the Hong Kong Government is proactive and considers it necessary to introduce a number of preventive measures to protect public health.

"The Inter-departmental Co-ordinating Committee on H5N1 convened this morning came up with a plan of action including tightened control on import of chicken, enhanced surveillance in both man and poultry, as well as improvements in environmental hygiene in markets."

She said that the Hong Kong Health Authority had been working very closely with the World Health Organisation (WHO) and the Centres for Disease Control (CDC) in USA in dealing with the investigation and study of this new strain of Influenza A H5N1 strain in man.

As one of the 110 surveillance centres for the monitoring of influenza, Hong Kong had played a vital part in detecting this new strain of flu in human.

The Department of Health was currently conducting four epidemiological studies to ascertain the mode of transmission.

CDC was conducting further tests on genetic sequencing of the virus and also working at full speed on the development of a test for blood samples taken.

WHO would distribute H5N1 virus testing kits to all of its Collaborating Centres around the world shortly for surveillance purpose.

However, time and more cases were required to provide scientific evidence that could be used for drawing up conclusive findings.

In the meantime, a lot of work had been done by the Department of Health and experts in this field to provide data for scientific analysis.

Of the seven cases being analysed so far, all were tested positive by the Hong Kong Government Virus Unit.

Six had been confirmed by the CDC while the remaining one was classified as "suspected" pending CDC's independent confirmation.

Two of these cases indicated exposure to poultry within the incubation period, but the histories of the remaining five cases were less clear.

"Over 550 interviews were conducted and 2,550 laboratory specimens were taken during the course of investigations," Dr Chan said.

Follow-up on patient contacts showed all those with flu like illness had recovered.

Results of throat swabs taken from contacts in the first few cases were all negative while results for the last three cases were pending.

Test results on the more than two thousand blood samples which could shed more light on the form of transmission could not be confirmed pending development and refinement of test by CDC.

So far, two patients had fully recovered, one under treatment in satisfactory condition, two under treatment in critical condition and two died.

In the meantime, two more cases were classified as "suspected" by the Department of Health, making the total number of Influenza A H5N1 cases in human nine.

The two latest cases involved a two-year-old boy and a three-year-old girl who were cousins of a confirmed case (five-year-old girl).

They had mild symptoms only and were now receiving treatment in hospital.

Their conditions were satisfactory.

Follow-up investigation of the two cases had already started.

The public would be kept informed of the latest development.

On treatment for this new strain of flu, Dr Chan said amantadine was found to be an effective agent if used during the early stage.

Such information had been made available to government doctors and private practitioners.

For the public, Dr Chan advised that the best way to combat influenza infection was to build up body resistance by having a proper diet with adequate exercise and rest.

"Good ventilation should also be maintained."

To prevent this avian flu, the public are advised to maintain good personal hygiene.

They should wash their hands thoroughly after handling live poultry.

They should also avoid coming into contact with sick or diseased poultry.

Dr Chan also pointed out that chicken cooked thoroughly were safe for eating.
19991026_026.e:
Swine flu sample confirmed

The Department of Health (DH) received confirmation from overseas reference laboratories that a sample of influenza A H3N2 virus isolated from a 10 month-old patient last month was of swine origin.

DH's Consultant on Community Medicine, Dr Mak Kwok-hang said today (Tuesday) that this finding, although not common, should not pose a public health threat since overseas experience found patients infected with swine flu H3N2 made full recoveries without complication.

"There is no indication that this swine flu could cause outbreaks in human population, nor is the virus known to be food-borne " Dr Mak said.

"While the Hong Kong Health Authority will continue its enhanced surveillance on influenza, the public should take normal measures to prevent influenza," he added.

On the first case of swine flu A H3N2 virus isolated in Hong Kong, Dr Mak said it involved a 10 month-old girl who had now fully recovered.

Further investigation found no evidence of secondary spread.

A throat sample was collected from this patient last month as part of the influenza surveillance programme in Hong Kong.

It was later identified as an atypical influenza A H3N2 strain and sent to overseas reference laboratories for further analysis.

Test result from the National Institute for Medical Research in the United Kingdom earlier found it to be of swine origin.

Similar result was also obtained recently from the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention in the United States.

To prevent influenza, members of the public are advised:

* to build up a good body immunity by having a proper diet, adequate exercise and rest;

* to maintain good ventilation to avoid the spread of germs;

* to avoid visiting crowded places with poor ventilation;

* to observe good personal hygiene;

* the young, elderly and those with chronic diseases should consult doctors promptly if they develop influenza-like symptoms.

19991103_016.e:
Pirated optical discs storage centres smashed

Professionalism displayed by the Customs officers of the Intellectual Property Investigation Bureau led to the neutralisation of two infringing optical discs storage and packaging centres operated by a piracy syndicate in Kowloon Bay yesterday (Tuesday).

During the operation, Customs officers seized over 280,000 pirated optical discs, worth about $4.3 million and arrested five suspects, including the mastermind of the syndicate.

After intensive investigations, Customs officers mounted a surveillance operation at a carpark in Sheung Yuet Street yesterday afternoon.

The officers intercepted three men and a woman seized about 1,100 pirated optical discs from two lorries.

Follow-up raids on two industrial units nearby resulted in the seizure of about 280,000 pirated optical discs, mainly VCDS and MCDs, and the arrest of the fourth suspect.

The arrested people, aged between 21 and 46, are now assisting Customs enquiries.

According to the Copyright Ordinance, anyone found selling pirated articles is liable to prosecution.

The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $50,000 per disc plus four years' imprisonment.

Last year, Customs officers seized 39 million pirated optical discs worth $960 million and arrested 1,645 people.

In the first nine months of this year, Customs officers have seized 12 million pirated optical discs with a market value of $220 million, and arrested 1,841 suspects.

"Our on-going anti-piracy operations signify the determination of the HKSAR Government in the protection of intellectual property rights," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department
19991124_013.e:
Pirated optical discs storage centre smashed

Professionalism displayed by the Customs officers of the Intellectual Property Investigation Bureau led to the neutralisation of an infringing optical discs storage and distribution centre operated by a piracy syndicate at a remote area in Sheung Shui yesterday (Tuesday).

During the operation, Customs officers seized over 39,000 pirated optical discs and impounded two vehicles, totally worth about $800,000, and arrested a 22-year-old man, believed to be the mastermind of the syndicate.

After intensive investigations, Customs officers raided a unit at Ki Lun Tsuen yesterday afternoon and made the seizure, mainly VCDS, MCDs and CD Roms, and impounded two vehicles.

Last year, Customs officers seized 39 million pirated optical discs worth $960 million and arrested 1,645 people.

In the first 10 months of this year, Customs officers have seized 13.88 million pirated optical discs with a market value of $330 million, and arrested 2,565 suspects.

According to the Copyright Ordinance, anyone found selling pirated articles is liable to prosecution.

The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $50,000 per disc plus four years' imprisonment.

Anyone operating a CD factory without a valid licence in Hong Kong is in breach of the Prevention of Copyright Piracy Ordinance.

The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $1 million and four years' imprisonment.

"Our on-going anti-piracy operations signify the determination of the HKSAR Government in the protection of intellectual property rights here in Hong Kong," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department
19991222_006.e:
Seizure of pirated discs by Customs

Customs officers of the Intellectual Property Investigation Bureau yesterday (Tuesday) seized from a Kwai Chung industrial unit more than 620,000 pirated optical discs, worth about $10 million, the biggest seizure by Customs in a single raid on pirated discs storage centre.

Following a three-week investigation, the officers yesterday afternoon raided the target premises in Kwai Chung.

As a result, they seized 410,000 pirated VCDs, 200,000 music CDs and 10,000 CD-Roms, all of infringing nature.

During the anti-piracy operation, three men, aged between 26 and 43, were arrested.

"Enquiries revealed that the piracy syndicate would receive their orders through fax.

Members of the syndicate will then deliver the pirated discs to the customers through different means, which had posed difficulties to Customs investigations," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department.

Last year, Customs officers seized 39 million pirated optical discs worth $960 million and arrested 1,645 people.

From January to November this year, Customs officers have seized 15.24 million pirated optical discs with a market value of $360 million, and arrested 2,439 suspects.

According to the Copyright Ordinance, anyone found selling pirated articles is liable to prosecution.

The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $50,000 per disc plus four years' imprisonment.

"Our on-going anti-piracy operations signify the determination of the SAR Government in the protection of intellectual property rights here in Hong Kong," the spokesman stressed.
19990223_010.e:
Seizure of pirated optical discs at airport

Customs officers at airport last Monday (February 15) seized a large quantity of pirated optical discs worth about $2 million from a cargo arriving from Malaysia via Singapore.

The case came to light in the afternoon last Monday when Customs officers examined the cargo declared to have contained blank recordable discs.

The officers, however, found 86,000 pirated VCDs of Japanese drama series, 19,000 pirated MP3 discs and television game discs as well as 57 disc replication stampers.

"No arrest has so far been made and enquiries by Customs Intellectual Property Investigation Bureau (IPIB) are continuing," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department today (Tuesday).

In another anti-piracy operation yesterday, the IPIB officers raided five shops selling pirated optical discs on Hong Kong island.

As a result, they seized more than $540,000 worth of pirated optical discs and arrested five people in connection with the seizure.

The spokesman noted that Customs officers last year seized 39 million pirated optical discs worth $1 billion and arrested 1,561 suspects.

In January this year, the officers seized 1.16 million pirated optical discs with a market value of $21 million and arrested 162 suspects, he went on.

He also appealed to members of the public to continue providing information on any suspected piracy activities.

"Information could be passed to the department by calling the 24-hour hotline 2545 4546," he added.

He warned that according to the Copyright Ordinance, anyone who was found importing or selling any pirated articles is liable to prosecution.

The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $50,000 per disc and four years' imprisonment.

"Our on-going anti-piracy operations demonstrate the SAR Government's determination and full commitment in combating piracy activities and preserving the good image of Hong Kong,"the spokesman added.
19990226_018.e:
Packaging and storage centre of pirated optical discs smashed

Customs officers of the Intellectual Property Investigation Bureau smashed a packaging and storage centre of pirated optical discs in Tuen Mun on Wednesday (February 24).

Following intensive investigation and surveillance, the officers raided an industrial unit in Tuen Mun and seized 210,000 pirated VCDs and 30,000 music CDs, totally worth about $3.8 million, and arrested a man in connection with the case.

"The neutralisation of this centre is resultant from vigilant enforcement actions by the Customs officers," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department today (Friday).

20000419_003.e:
Contemporary French Art Exhibition Opens at Museum of Art

"Why Art?"

"What is the New?" - declarations of art from Ben, a Fluxus member of Nice.

Do you wish to know what the Fluxus are and their spirit to identify art with life?

Do you wish to know what New Realism is and how the French artists of 1960s and 1970s faced the material world and popularize art with living?

If the answer is yes, then you should not miss "Nice Movements - Contemporary French Art" Exhibition to be held at Hong Kong Museum of Art.

The exhibition, one of the major programmes of Le French May, was opened this evening (April 19).

Fifty-six masterpieces by 11 noted artists active in Nice are featured in this exhibition, offering the audience a glimpse of the various significant art movements from the 1960s to 1970s.

The exhibition will be opened to the public from tomorrow (April 20) to June 25, 2000.

The officiating guests of the opening ceremony were Secretary for Home Affairs Mr David Lan and Consul General of France in Hong Kong Mr Jerome Pasquier.

Speaking at the ceremony, Mr Lan said the opening of the exhibition marked the launching of the eighth French May Festival in Hong Kong.

He said, "We are proud to join hands with the Consulate General of France to present this significant cultural event.

The exhibition gives Hong Kong people an excellent opportunity to appreciate the essence of contemporary French art.

No doubt, it will also bring fresh inspirations to local artists,"

"The cities of Nice and Hong Kong share certain similarities.

Both are beautiful places in their own ways.

Whereas Nice experienced new art movements in the 1960s and 1970s, Hong Kong artists also attempted artistic explorations in the two decades with different accomplishments.

I hope that the two cities will establish a closer relationship by way of cultural exchanges, contributing to further enhancement of their arts," Mr Lan added.

Mr Lan also thanked the Consulate General of France for bringing the annual French May exhibitions which brightened up Hong Kong so much.

The exhibition features the artists such as Cesar, Klein, Arman, Raysse, Gilli and Bernar Venet who were pioneers of the New Realism, Pop and Conceptual.

All of them devoted to create works of painting, assemblage and collage by using consumers' product, junk and other daily objects to link up art and the life of people with social messages.

Among them, Yves Klein placed more emphasis on gestures and symbolic actions and was much acclaimed for his blue paint - "International Klein Blue".

Ben and other Fluxus artists of the period pronounced a spirit of anarchism and denounced the formalities of art, making it no difference from life.

Ben's boxes and crates jammed with found objects and inscription paintings fully illustrate the Fluxus spirit that "Everything is Art", "Non-Art" or even "Anti-Art".

The formation of the Supports/Surfaces group was an outcome of theorization, politicization, regional disputes as well as a quest for freedom and pleasure and to repel conventions.

Artists of this group recaptured the true essence of painting.

Works by these artists were not only confined to the canvas, but also extended to fabric, stamping and constructions, thus making painting a vehicle of the society.

Emergence of these art trends ultimately contributed to the formation of the so-called I'Ecole de Nice (School of Nice) which has profound influence on the evolvement of contemporary art.

These artists' representative works are on show in the exhibition.

The exhibition is jointly presented by the Leisure and Cultural Services Department and the Consulate General of France, Hong Kong; supported by the Association Francaise d'Action Artistique, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, France; sponsored by LVMH/Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton; guest curated by Mr Jean-Francois Mozziconacci, Director of Nice Museums and organised by the Hong Kong Museum of Art.

Also officiating at the ceremony were Finance Director of LVMH/Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton Mr Remy Husson, Director of Nice Museums Mr Jean-Francois Mozziconacci, Director of Leisure and Cultural Services Mr Paul Leung Sai-wah, and Acting Chief Curator of Hong Kong Museum of Art Dr Christina Chu.

To coincide the exhibition, a fully illustrated catalogue has been published and free education pamphlets are issued.

CD-ROM audio guide service is available and a series of education and extension activities are organised.

The Hong Kong Museum of Art is located at 10 Salisbury Road, Tsim Sha Tsui.

It opens from 10 am to 6 pm daily (including Sundays and public holidays) and closes on Thursdays (except April 20, 2000).

Admission fee is $10, with half-price concessions for senior citizens, people with disabilities and full-time students.

Members of the public are welcome to browse the Museum's website at http://www.lcsd.gov.hk/hkma/.

"The Cobra Movement - 50 Years" Exhibition Opens Today

The following is issued on behalf of the Provisional Urban Council:

Here comes the Cobra!

The "Cobra" currently shown at the Museum of Art has nothing to do with the poisonous snake.

It is in fact the name of an art movement initiated by European avant-garde artists.

The word "Cobra" is an anagram formed from the initial letters of the European capitals - Copenhagen, Brussels and Amsterdam.

It represents the blending of individual components into one single entity.

The Movement, active from 1948 to 1951, was an important art movement after the Second World War.

It was formed by a group of artists mainly from Denmark, Belgium and the Netherlands.

The artists gathered at the back-room of a Paris cafe near Notre Dame in November 1948 and started the Movement then.

With inspiration from primitive art and drawings by children and the mentally deranged, the Cobra artists sought to liberate art from the norms of Western tradition.

As Corneille, a well-known Cobra artist, put it well, "'Cobra' is a vital cry - a bright splash of colour in all its force - as if the hand of the artist was crying out against the formalism which holds it a prisoner¡K¡K".

Officiating at the opening ceremony of "The Cobra Movement - 50 Years" exhibition at the Hong Kong Museum of Art today (Thursday), the Provisional Urban Council Chairman, Dr Ronald Leung Ding-bong, said that the Cobra artists' ideas were enshrined in a manifesto, and the artists shared the same social commitment in the hope of popularizing art.

"I hope the purity, primitiveness and expressiveness intrinsic in the art of the Cobra artists can enrich our citizens' perception of art and inspire our local artists," Dr Leung said.

Also officiating at today's opening ceremony are the world - renowned collector of Cobra art and owner of the exhibits, Mr Karel Van Stuijvenberg; the Consul General of Belgium, Ms Godelieve Van Den Bergh; the Consul General of Denmark, Mr Jens Peder Jensen; and the Consul General of the Netherlands, Mr Jochum S. Haakma.

Presented by the Provisional Urban Council and the Consulates General of Belgium, Denmark and the Netherlands of Hong Kong, the exhibition features 74 items of painting and sculpture selected from the Cobra Museum for Modern Art in Amstelveen, the Netherlands.

The exhibition will open to public from tomorrow until April 11, 1999.

A fully illustrated catalogue which provides detailed information on the exhibition will be on sale at the Museum's gift shop.

Last Ten Days for Baroque Italian Paintings at Museum of Art

"Classical Italian Painting - Guercino and His School" exhibition has attracted about 25,000 visitors since its opening four weeks ago.

Members of the public who are interested in viewing the masterpieces by Italian Baroque painters of 17th century are reminded to visit the Hong Kong Museum of Art before the exhibition closes on March 5, 2000.

Evolved from the late Renaissance movement, the art of Baroque reached its peak in the 17th century.

Originating in Italy, the art of Baroque also flourished in many European countries and stayed in the spotlight for over a century.

The artistic style of Baroque was also reflected in sculpture, architecture, music and literature.

Baroque master Guercino, Giovan Francesco Barbieri, (1591 - 1666) was a major successor of Carracci Academism of the Baroque period and a renowned painter in Bologna, Italy.

His works inherited Raphael's fine equilibrium and harmony as well as Carravagio's chiaroscuro and naturalistic expression.

In addition to Guercino's works, the exhibition also features representative works by artists including Carracci Brothers, Reni, Lanfranco and Domenichino in order to fully illustrate the artistic achievements of the Bologna School in the early 17th century Baroque movement.

The 31 masterpieces, being displayed in the Orient for the very first time, are selected from the Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Antica, Palazzo Barberini and institutes in Italy.

Jointly presented by the Leisure and Cultural Services Department and the Consolato Generale d'Italia Hong Kong, the exhibition is organised by the Hong Kong Museum of Art and the Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Antica, Palazzo Barberini.

To coincide with the exhibition, a children painting corner and a reading corner are specially set up in the gallery.

Chinese Dinosaurs are Coming to Town

The following is issued on behalf of the Provisional Urban Council:

You better watch out.

Fourteen Chinese prehistoric giants are coming to town!

A large-scale exhibition entitled "Chinese Dinosaur Fossils" featuring magnificent dinosaur skeletons will be staged at the Special Exhibition Gallery of the Hong Kong Science Museum from tomorrow (Tuesday) to June 11, 2000.

Speaking at the opening ceremony this afternoon, the Chairman of the Provisional Urban Council's Museums Select Committee, Mr Mok Ying-fan, said that the Council had always concentrated its effort in popularising science and its related activities.

"We presented the 'Dinosaur Alive' and 'Prehistoric Giants' exhibitions in 1993 and 1996 respectively.

These two exhibitions on robotic dinosaurs had been very well received.

This year, 14 genuine dinosaur fossils from China will be displayed," Mr Mok said.

Mr Mok said these exhibits were selected from the fine collections of Beijing Natural History Museum, Chongqing Natural History Museum and Zigong Dinosaur Museum.

They included the Mamenchisaurus, the one with the longest neck in the dinosaurs' family; the Huayangosaurus, known as the very primitive stegosaurus; and the Tuojiangosaurus, the dinosaur which had the largest number of bony plates.

"A precious collection of fossil specimens uncovered in China will also be featured, ranging from the ancient animal and plant fossils, fossils of dinosaur bones, skull, teeth, eggs to the footprints of dinosaurs," he noted.

"In terms of scale, this is the largest exhibition of dinosaur fossils ever held in China.

Even if we make a trip to the Mainland museums, we would not be able to see so many fossil specimens at one time," he added.

Also officiating at the opening ceremony were the President of Guangdong Southern Natural Museum, Mr Zhang Jingyuan; the Secretary of Zi Gong Municipal Committee, Mr Wang Dongzhou; the Assistant Director, Head of Publicity And Cultural And Sports Department of the Xinhua News Agency (Hong Kong Branch), Mr Sun Nan Sheng; the Deputy Secretary-General of Chinese Association of National Science Museums, Professor Zhen Shuonan, and the Deputy Director of Urban Services (Culture), Ms Choi Suk-kuen.

Surrounded by the prehistoric forest settings, visitors will have the opportunity to explore the dinosaurs' lives in their habitat.

They can also play the role as a fossil detective to identify the differences between carnivorous and herbivorous dinosaurs in the "Fossil Detective" game.

In addition, they can challenge themselves on the knowledge of dinosaurs in the "Dinosaur Quiz" computer game.

To supplement the exhibition, various extension activities such as popular science lectures, fun science experiments, Chinese dinosaurs paper cutting demonstration and film shows will be held in the Museum during the exhibition period.

This large-scale exhibition is presented by the Provisional Urban Council in association with the Chinese Association of Natural Science Museums and the Guangdong Southern Natural Museum.

It is one of the major events of the two Municipal Councils to celebrate the new millennium and also a Spotlight Hong Kong Event supported by the Hong Kong Tourist Association.

The Hong Kong Science Museum is located at 2 Science Museum Road, Tsim Sha Tsui East.

Admission fee for the exhibition is $30 (for both permanent exhibitions and "Chinese Dinosaur Fossils" exhibition), and $10 (for "Chinese Dinosaur Fossils" exhibition only), with half-price concessions for senior citizens, people with disabilities and full-time students.

Admission for permanent exhibitions is free on Wednesdays but this does not apply to "Chinese Dinosaur Fossils" exhibition.

20000127_015.e:
Baroque Italian Paintings on Show at Museum of Art

An exhibition of the beautiful fruits of human imagination and artistry - "Classical Italian Painting - Guercino and His School" was opened this (Thursday) afternoon.

Thirty-one masterpieces by Italian Baroque painters of 17th century are on display in the Orient for the very first time.

The exhibition will be opened to the public at the Hong Kong Museum of Art from tomorrow (January 28) to March 5, 2000.

The officiating guests of the opening ceremony were Secretary for Home Affairs, Mr David Lan and Consul General of Italy, Mr Pietro Giovanni Donnici.

Speaking at the ceremony, Mr Lan noted that it was very kind of the National Gallery of Art in Rome to bring gems of its prestigious collection to Hong Kong in celebration of the Millennium.

"The Hong Kong Museum of Art, now under the newly established Leisure and Cultural Services Department, has established an international reputation of fostering cultural exchanges," Mr Lan said.

"Though the Museum's collection is predominantly Chinese, it regularly cooperates with various consulates and cultural institutions to bring in major international art exhibitions for the people of Hong Kong,"

"This year, in addition to the Classical Italian Painting Exhibition, the Museum will present exhibitions on contemporary French art from Nice, Japanese art from the Tokyo National Museum, new Chinese art from the United States and Buddhist sculptures from the Mainland.

This programme of international exhibitions will contribute to the continued development of Hong Kong as the cultural hub of Asia," Mr Lan added.

In the full glory of Renaissance, western art in the 15th and 16th centuries was evoked by humanism, when people were enlightened with a new vision to religion and the universe.

Evolved from the late Renaissance movement, the art of Baroque reached its peak in the 17th century.

This style of art is characterized with dynamics, movement and fervour expressed in chiaroscuro and intensified dramatic lighting.

Originating in Italy, the art of Baroque also flourished in many European countries and stayed in the spotlight for over a century.

The artistic style of Baroque was also reflected in sculpture, architecture, music and literature.

Baroque master Guercino, Giovan Francesco Barbieri, (1591 - 1666) was a major successor of Carracci Academism of the Baroque period and a renowned painter in Bologna, Italy.

His works inherited Raphael's fine equilibrium and harmony as well as Carravagio's chiaroscuro and naturalistic expression, with a direct reference to the main stream of Baroque art in Rome and Venice.

In addition to Guercino's works, the exhibition also features representative works by artists of the Bologna School including Carracci Brothers, Reni, Lanfranco and Domenichino in order to fully illustrate the artistic achievements of the Bologna School in the early 17th century Baroque movement.

Distinguished works such as "Saul Versus David" by Guercino; "Flora with Putti" by Francesco Albani and "The Burning of Troy" by Alessandro Tiarini will also be shown.

The 31 masterpieces are selected from the Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Antica, Palazzo Barberini and institutes in Italy.

Jointly presented by the Leisure and Cultural Services Department and the Consolato Generale d'Italia Hong Kong, the exhibition is organised by the Hong Kong Museum of Art and the Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Antica, Palazzo Barberini.

Also officiating at the ceremony were Director of Leisure and Cultural Services, Mr Paul Leung Sai-wah; President of the Italian Cultural Society of Hong Kong 'Dante Alighieri', Dr Leo Lee; Storico dell'arte Direttore, Galleria Nazional d'Arte Antica, Palazzo Barberini, Dr Rossella Vodret and Chief Curator, Hong Kong Museum of Art, Mr Gerard Tsang.

To coincide with the exhibition, a children painting corner and a reading corner are specially set up in the gallery.

A gallery talk will be held tomorrow (Friday) afternoon from 5.30 pm to 7 pm at the Special Gallery of the Museum with Dr Rossella Vodret as the speaker.

Enquiries for the talk can be made on 2734 2156.

The Museum of Art is located at 10 Salisbury Road, Tsim Sha Tsui.

Admission fee for this exhibition is $10, with half-price concessions for senior citizens, people with disabilities and full-time students.

Admission is free on Wednesdays.

The Museum opens daily from 10 am to 6 pm (including Sundays and public holidays).

It is closed on Thursdays and the first two days of the Chinese New Year (February 5 and 6), and closed at 5 pm on Chinese New Year's Eve (February 4).

Members of the public are welcome to browse the Museum's website at http://www.lcsd.gov.hk/hkma/.

For enquiries, please call 2721 0116.

Opening Hours of Museum of Art Extended

To upgrade museum services, the Leisure and Cultural Services Department will extend the opening hours of the Hong Kong Museum of Art from Sunday (January 23).
