19981217_011.e:
No let-up in efforts to ease unemployment

The provisional seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for the period September - November 1998 was 5.5 per cent, and the provisional underemployment rate was 2.9 per cent, according to the latest labour force statistics released today (Thursday) by the Census and Statistics Department.

For the period August - October 1998, the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was revised marginally downwards, from the earlier provisional figure of 5.3 per cent to 5.2 per cent, while the underemployment rate remained the same as the earlier provisional figure of 2.7 per cent.

Comparing the period September - November 1998 with August - October 1998, the increase in unemployment rate occurred mainly in the decoration and maintenance, manufacturing, business services, import/export trades and transport sectors.

As to the underemployment rate, increases were seen in the manufacturing, decoration and maintenance and retail sectors.

The unemployment and underemployment rates in the other major sectors remained relatively stable.

For the period August - October 1998, the size of the total labour force was 3,388,900, of whom 3,200,200 were employed and 188,700 were unemployed.

In the same period, the number of underemployed persons was 92,500.

For the period September - November 1998, the size of the total labour force was provisionally estimated at 3,391,000, while the number of unemployed persons and underemployed persons were provisionally estimated at 191,000 and 99,000 respectively.

Commenting on the latest figures, the Government Economist, Mr K Y Tang, said that both the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate and the underemployment rate showed a further rise in September - November, as the downward adjustment in the economy continued along with reduced business volumes and further down-sizing in the corporate sector.

He added that on current indications, and having regard to the fact that both are lagged indicators of economic activity, the unemployment and underemployment rates were likely to stay high in the near term.

The Secretary for Education and Manpower, Mr Joseph W P Wong, reaffirmed the Government's commitment to do everything within its powers to help the unemployed return to the workforce as soon as possible.

"Hong Kong is undergoing a major economic adjustment brought on largely by repercussions of the regional financial turmoil.

Unemployment will remain on the high side for some time as a result of corporate downsizing and layoffs during this process.

"However, several positive developments have emerged in the most recent period.

These include declining local interest rates, moderating inflation and a rebound in asset prices, which have helped to improve sentiments in the local market.

These, together with the inherent flexibility of our economy, should enable Hong Kong to emerge more robust and competitive in the longer term," he said.

Mr Wong pointed out that employment prospects remained positive in the longer run.

"We are finalising a comprehensive update on our recent job creation assessment, taking into account the latest progress of the Government's policy initiatives and infrastructural commitments.

We plan to complete the exercise in January 1999," he said.

Mr Wong also pointed out that Government would launch a massive programme of infrastructure and public works projects over the coming few years.

Since May 1998, 177 works contracts worth a total of $10 billion have started and some 13,000 jobs have been created.

The Government will continue to consider the possibility of accelerating the commencement of more projects.

Mr Wong added that the tourism sector continued to improve in recent months.

"Total tourist arrival figures have consistently been higher than the corresponding figures last year.

In October, total tourist arrivals amounted to 854,000, 0.2 per cent up from October last year.

The hotel occupancy rate has also been steadily rising.

It stood at 82 per cent in October, as compared with 76 per cent in October last year.

This will have positive spin-off effects on a host of other related sectors--aviation, retail, catering, restaurant, and transport services, and generate employment opportunities.

Meanwhile, some 600 applications involving a total loan amount of $862 million have so far been approved under the Special Finance Scheme for Small and Medium Enterprises.

This should help relieve the liquidity problem facing many small and medium enterprises which form the backbone of our economy.

This will in turn help to sustain and create jobs in the labour market.

Turning to the impact of retrenchments and wage cuts on affected employees, Mr Wong said that he continued to be very concerned about the situation.

"We appeal to both employers and employees to resolve their problems through sincere and frank discussions at the enterprise level, and seek the assistance of the Labour Department as and when necessary.

They should also make full use of the 'Guidelines on What to Do if Wage Reductions and Retrenchments are Unavoidable' recently issued by the Labour Department.

"To strengthen the protection of employees' wages against the impact of employers becoming insolvent, and that of pay cuts, we intend to increase the maximum limit of the ex-gratia payment on severance payment under the Protection of Wages on Insolvency Fund and enable such ex-gratia payment to be calculated on the basis of an employee's wage before any wage reduction if the employer has so undertaken in writing.

These proposals were endorsed by the Protection of Wages on Insolvency Fund Board earlier this month.

We will be consulting the Labour Advisory Board next week and aim at introducing the relevant legislative items into LegCo before the Chinese New Year," Mr Wong added.

Mr Wong said that the Government had been implementing a wide-ranging series of measures to help the unemployed to rejoin the workforce and equip them with the requisite skills to stay competitive in the labour market.

The Labour Department is providing a full range of strengthened services to help unemployed job-seekers find jobs.

Despite the increasing number of unemployed persons in recent months, the Department has still managed to find jobs for an average of around 4,000 people each month.

The Department will set up a Telephone Employment Service Centre in North Point by the end of this month to further strengthen the telephone referral service.

To enhance operational efficiency, a Job Vacancy Processing Centre will also be set up to centralise the receipt and processing vacancy orders.

As regards training and retraining, all the additional training and retraining programmes for the unemployed and school leavers have commenced.

"The LegCo Finance Committee recently approved a further capital grant of $500 million to the Employees Retraining Board (ERB).

It is now formulating a full-fledged strategic plan to expand its training capacity to meet the increasing demand, and to improve the quality of its various training programmes for the unemployed.

It will, in particular, embark on the major exercise of consolidating the curricula of its mainstream courses to pave the way for the development of a qualifications framework in conjunction with the Vocational Training Council.

The demand for part-time local domestic helpers remains large relative to supply, despite rising unemployment.

Ever since ERB's one-stop service came into operation on July 9, 1998, some 1,200 vacancies were received and 335 have been filled by graduate retrainees.

ERB is working closely with its training bodies to organise more retraining courses and match the retrainees with job vacancies in different districts more effectively.

The survey for August - October 1998 covered a quarterly sample of some 23,800 households or 78,500 persons, selected in accordance with a scientifically designed sampling scheme to represent the land-based civilian non-institutional population in Hong Kong.

Data on labour force characteristics were obtained from the survey by interviewing each member aged 15 or over in the households sampled.

In the survey, the definitions used in measuring unemployment and underemployment follow closely those recommended by the International Labour Organisation.

The unemployment rate is 'seasonally adjusted'.

This refers to the fact that it has been adjusted for seasonal variations in the proportion of first-time job-seekers in the labour force.

Detailed analysis of labour force characteristics is given in the report on the General Household Survey which is published four times a year.

The next report covering the quarter ending December 1998 will be on sale at the Government Publications Centre at ground floor, Low Block, 66 Queensway, Hong Kong, by early March 1999.

19981019_012.e:
All-out efforts to ease unemployment continues

The provisional seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for the period July - September 1998 was 5.0 per cent, and the provisional underemployment rate was 2.6 per cent, according to the latest labour force statistics released today (Monday) by the Census and Statistics Department.

For the period June - August 1998, the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate remained the same as the earlier provisional figure of 5.0 per cent, while the underemployment rate was revised marginally upwards, from the earlier provisional figure of 2.5 per cent to 2.6 per cent.

Comparing the period July - September 1998 with June - August 1998, an increase in the unemployment rate was seen in the construction sector, but some decrease was seen in the clothing and footwear sector.

As to the underemployment rate, increases mainly occurred in the construction and restaurants sectors, but a decrease occurred in the retail sector.

The unemployment and underemployment rates in the other major sectors remained relatively stable.

For the period June - August 1998, the size of the total labour force was 3,380,300, of whom 3,205,400 were employed and 174,900 were unemployed.

In the same period, the number of underemployed persons was 86,400.

For the period July - September 1998, the number of unemployed persons and underemployed persons were provisionally estimated at 181,000 and 89,000 respectively.

The Government Economist, Mr K Y Tang said that the latest stabilisation in both the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate and underemployment rate was notable, after the sharp upsurge in the earlier months.

But lay-offs and wage-cuts were still reported most recently, and the adjustment to the adversities in the labour market was expected to continue for the time being.

The Secretary for Education and Manpower, Mr Joseph W P Wong, reiterated that the Government would continue to spare no efforts in helping the unemployed rejoin the workforce as soon as possible.

"Hong Kong has been adjusting and adapting efficiently to the repercussions of the regional financial turmoil.

Our property market seems to be stabilising, and interest rates have been reduced by 0.25% with effect from today.

This should have a helpful effect on local sentiment and hence possibly the employment situation.

"Our tourism sector continues to rebound.

Tourist arrival figures have been increasing--from 833,000 in July to 859,000 in August.

Our hotel occupancy rate has also been rising from 76 per cent in July to 79 per cent in August.

This will have a positive spin-off impact on a host of other related sectors - aviation, travel, retail, catering, restaurant, and transport services," Mr Wong said.

The Special Finance Scheme for Small and Medium Enterprises has been running smoothly.

A total of 135 applications involving a total loan amount of $252 million has so far been approved.

This, together with the latest cut in interest rates, should help relieve the liquidity problem facing many small and medium enterprises, and generate a stimulating effect on the economy.

"Employment prospects remain positive.

According to the Government's recent assessment, there will be at least some 100,000 job vacancies in the labour market by the end of 1999, largely as a result of the Government's key policy initiatives and major infrastructure or other projects, and partly because of the needs of the Civil Service.

Of these, around 15,000 have been created by mid-September.

We will produce an updated assessment by the end of this year in the light of the new initiatives and infrastructural projects set out in the 1998 Policy Address," Mr Wong said.

"We remain concerned about the impact of retrenchments and wage cuts on affected employees.

Maintaining harmonious labour relations is essential for Hong Kong's economic competitiveness.

We therefore urge all employers affected by the current economic downturn to discuss their difficulties with their employees, with a view to reaching mutually acceptable agreements.

To facilitate such communications, the Labour Department has drafted a Code of Practice on how employers should properly handle problems arising from the need for retrenchments and pay adjustments.

The Labour Advisory Board will be consulted on this at its meeting on October 23(this Friday)," Mr Wong added.

Meanwhile, the wide-ranging series of measures to ease unemployment and facilitate job creation announced by the Task Force on Employment are all in full swing.

On employment services, the Labour Department is providing a full range of strengthened services to help unemployed job-seekers find jobs.

They include a strengthened Job Matching Programme; extended access to job vacancy information through more touch-screen computers and the Internet; a telephone job matching service; and an increasing number of job vacancies open for direct application from job-seekers.

Despite the increasing number of unemployed persons during the last two months, the Department has managed to find jobs for an average of 4,000 people each month.

On training and retraining, all the additional training programmes for the unemployed and school leavers have commenced.

These include:

- The special nine-month Certificate of Skills Training (Service Industries) Course for 1,000 unemployed persons which started on September 14;

- The first class of the special seafarers training course which started on September 9;

- The special one-year full-time Vocational Studies Certificate programme for 1000 Secondary 5 leavers which started on October 12; and

- The one-year full-time Construction Supervisor/Technician Training Programme (totalling 600 training places) and six short courses lasting for about three months (totalling 916 training places) run by the Construction Industry Training Authority for Secondary 5 leavers which started in mid-September.

On promoting further education, classes for the additional 1,000 Secondary 5 places in Government evening schools commenced on September 16.

Six UGC-funded institutions are prepared to over-enrol by 10 per cent to 20 per cent at the Taught Post-graduate levels in the 1998/99 academic year.

The Student Financial Assistance Agency has also started receiving applications for the Non-Means-Tested Loan Scheme which has been extended to benefit some 61,000 more tertiary students, including those at the Open University.

On employees retraining, the Employees Retraining Board(ERB) has decided to expand its total training capacity by 6,000 to 79,000 in 1998/99.

This will increase its total expenditure to $396 million this year, up 80 per cent from 1997/98.

To ensure that ERB will have adequate funds to expand its training capacity and improve the quality of its training programmes for the unemployed over the next few years, the Government will provide it with another capital grant of $500 million.

Including this grant, total Government grant to ERB will amount to $1.6 billion, and ERB will have an estimated total of $800 million to implement its programmes at the beginning of 1999/2000.

"We will sustain our efforts to help the unemployed to re-enter the labour market and hold down their jobs.

To this end, we will continue to work closely with the Task Force on Employment, which will have its fifth meeting on 21 October (this Wednesday)," Mr Wong stressed.

Data on labour force characteristics were obtained from the survey by interviewing each member aged 15 or over in the households sampled.

19980615_017.e:
Government making sustained efforts to tackle unemployment

The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for the period February - April 1998 was 3.9 per cent, and the underemployment rate was 2.2 per cent, according to the latest labour force statistics released today (Monday) by the Census and Statistics Department.

For the period March - May 1998, the provisional seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was 4.2 per cent, while the provisional underemployment rate was 2.6 per cent.

Explaining the changes in these figures, the acting Government Economist, Miss Elley Mao, said, "Comparing the period March - May 1998 with February - April 1998, the increase in unemployment rate occurred mainly in retail, restaurants and transport sectors.

By comparison, the unemployment situation in the other major sectors was broadly stable.

As to the underemployment rate, the increase was concentrated in construction, manufacturing and transport sectors.

The underemployment situation in the other major sectors was also generally stable."

"In the three months ending April 1998, total labour supply was 3,298,300, of whom 3,176,700 were employed and 121,700 were unemployed.

In the same period, the number of underemployed persons was 72,400," she added.

Speaking at a meet-the-media session today, the Secretary for Education and Manpower, Mr Joseph W P Wong said that he was deeply concerned about the rise in unemployment rate and was acutely aware of the difficulties faced by the unemployed.

He reaffirmed the Government's commitment to do everything within its power to help the unemployed to re-enter the labour market.

"Employment prospects in foreseeable future are, however, positive.

This underlines the fact that Hong Kong's economic fundamentals remain sound and strong.

There will be at least some 100,000 job vacancies in the labour market over the coming one and a half years, largely as a result of the Government's key policy initiatives and major projects, and partly because of the growth of the Civil Service.

These vacancies comprise 11,000 in the civil service during the coming year and 89,000 outside the Government.

"The Government will be spending about $235 billion on infrastructural and public works building projects in the next five years which is 50 per cent over the seven-year Airport Core Projects.

These projects will altogether generate some 60,000 job opportunities during the coming 18 months.

We will advance by two to five months the start date of five public works projects costing nearly $1.3 billion and which will create some 530 jobs by the end of this year or early next year.

We will continue to explore the possibility of expediting the progress of other projects with a view to generating more job opportunities at an earlier time," Mr Wong said.

"The present unemployment problem arises from an economic adjustment which Hong Kong is undergoing.

This process was triggered largely by the financial turmoil and the unstable economic conditions in the Asian region.

Short of the onset of an economic recovery, there are no quick fixes to the problem.

"The Government alone cannot tackle the unemployment situation.

It calls for sustained, collective and concerted efforts of the whole community.

The private sector has a key role to play.

It was also for this reason that the Task Force on Employment was formed," Mr Wong added.

"The Task Force has got off to a useful start at its first meeting on June 3, with the promulgation of a 12-point package of further measures to create jobs and tackle unemployment.

We are pressing ahead with the various measures at full steam.

The Task Force will continue with its efforts to ease unemployment.

The next meeting of the Task Force is scheduled for July 9," he said.

"Despite the rising unemployment, the Labour Department has managed to find jobs for an increasing number of job-seekers over the past few months.

Following a 34 per cent increase in placements to 2,540 in April over March, the figure rose further to 2,980 in May.

There are also some 15,600 live vacancies currently on the register of the Labour Department.

"All the new measures to improve employment services of the Labour Department, i.e. strengthening of the Job Matching Programme (JMP), provision of telephone job matching service, installation of additional touch-screen computers and launching of an Employment Information and Promotion Programme, will all take effect within the next two months.

The enhancement of the JMP and the telephone job matching service will start in early July.

These will go a long way towards improving the efficiency and effectiveness of the Department's employment services so that it can help more unemployed find jobs," Mr Wong said.

"The Employees Retraining Board (ERB) and the Vocational Training Council (VTC) will jointly launch a special nine-month full-time Certificate of Skills Training (Service Industries) Course for the unemployed with 1,000 places.

They will invite applications next month and the course will commence in September.

"This retraining course will be the first of its kind in the employees retraining history in Hong Kong.

It will be taught in flexible three-month modules, and retrainees will be streamed according to their skills standards.

It will emphasise on skills competence, and will put in place a comprehensive performance monitoring system comprising entry tests, continuous assessment and exit examinations upon the completion of each module," Mr Wong explained.

Mr Wong stressed that those who had successfully completed this course should be able to perform a wide range of office duties independently and competently in the services sector, especially in small and medium enterprises.

This will not only enable the unemployed to find and secure their jobs, but will also upgrade the overall quality and competitiveness of our workforce.

19980922_022.e:
Seizure of dutiable cigarettes by Customs

Customs officers of Lok Ma Chau Control Point yesterday (Monday) seized 1.8 million dutiable cigarettes worth about $2.3 million, with a duty potential of $1.4 million, from an incoming vehicle.

About 11 am yesterday, an incoming lorry was intercepted by Customs officers for examination at Lok Ma Chau Control Point.

The driver, a 48-year-old man, declared on a manifest that the lorry was carrying 175 packages of textile products.

Upon inspection, 180 cartons containing the contraband cigarettes were found hidden behind the manifested goods.

Follow-up investigations by the Customs General Investigation Division revealed that the cigarettes were destined for Hong Kong.

The driver will appear at the Fanling Magistracy on October 9 to face the charge of "importing unmanifested cargo" under the Import and Export Ordinance.

The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $500,000 and imprisonment of two years.
19990624_023.e:
Seizure of dutiable cigarettes by Customs

Speedy action by Customs officers led to the seizure of 2.2 million sticks of dutiable cigarettes worth about $2.9 million within an hour yesterday (Wednesday).

Acting on information, Customs Officers of the Anti-cigarettes Smuggling Task Force intercepted two suspected vehicles for search at a Kowloon Bay carpark at about 3 pm yesterday.

As a result, they seized 1.2 million contraband cigarettes from the vehicles.

During the operation, the officers also arrested five men, aged between 29 and 47.

About an hour later, Customs Officers approached two suspected vehicles for search inside a carpark at Mei Lam Estate in Tai Wai.

The officers arrested three men, aged between 35 and 40, and seized 1 million dutiable cigarettes.

" In both cases, the vehicles are believed to be mobile storage responsible for supplying dutiable cigarette to contraband cigarette distributors in Kowloon East, Shatin and Tai Po areas," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department.

The arrested will be charged under the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance.

The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $1 million and imprisonment of two years.

"The Department will continue its vigorous enforcement actions to check the supply of dutiable cigarettes to show the determination in protecting public revenue," the spokesman stressed.
19990323_012.e:
Seizure of dutiable cigarettes by Customs

Customs officers yesterday (Monday) seized 2.73 million sticks of dutiable cigarettes, which carried a market value of $3.6 million and a duty potential of $2.09 million, in Tai Po.

Acting on intelligence, Customs Officers of the Anti-cigarettes Smuggling Task Force intercepted a cross-boundary lorry inside a carpark near Yuen Chau Tsai in Tai Po for search.

As a result, they made the seizure and arrested the driver, a 32-year-old man.

"The cigarettes are believed to be imported into Hong Kong through Lok Ma Chau Control Point earlier yesterday.

The vehicle is believed to be a mobile storage responsible for supplying dutiable cigarettes to contraband cigarette distributors in Sheung Shui, Fanling, Tai Po, Sha Tin and Kowloon City areas," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department.

The arrested driver has been charged under the Import and Export Ordinance.

The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $2 million and imprisonment of seven years.

"The Department will continue its vigorous enforcement actions to check the supply of dutiable cigarettes to show the determination in protecting public revenue," the spokesman stressed.
19980910_009.e:
Seizure of dutiable cigarettes by Customs

Customs officers yesterday (Wednesday) seized 200,000 sticks of smuggled cigarettes and arrested 16 suspects in a territory wide anti-cigarette-smuggling operation.

The value of the seizure is about $270,000, with a duty potential of $150,000.

During the operation code-named "Tornado 105", officers from the Customs Marine and Land Enforcement Command raided several black spots of selling smuggled cigarettes and made the seizure.

The arrested, aged between 23 and 58, have been charged with "dealing with goods to which Dutiable Commodities Ordinance applies".

"Any person found committing the offence, including dealing, selling or purchasing dutiable commodities, will be subject to a maximum penalty of $1 million fine and two years' imprisonment," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department.

The department would continue their anti-cigarette-smuggling operations to smash distribution centres of contraband cigarettes, he added.
19991029_009.e:
Seizure of smuggled cigarettes by Customs

Customs officers of the General Investigation Division last (Thursday) night foiled a smuggling attempt case following the seizure of more than 13 million sticks of dutiable cigarettes, which carried a market value of $17.2 million, and a duty potential of $10 million, on Lautau Island as a result of their constant efforts in combating smuggling activities.

Acting on intelligence and following intensive investigations, Customs officers mounted a surveillance operation at Tung Chung Waterfront Road yesterday.

At about 9:30 pm, the officers swung into action when seeing several men moving hundreds of boxes ashore from two mainland vessels on board three vehicles.

Customs officers intercepted the men immediately and seized a total of 13.21 million sticks of dutiable cigarettes.

Nineteen crew members, all mainlanders, aged between 25 to 43, and six local residents, aged between 26 to 42, were arrested.

The masters of both vessels will appear at Tsuen Wan Magistracy tomorrow, charged with the offence of "Importing unmanifested cargo" under the Import and Export Ordinance.

The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $2 million and imprisonment for seven years.

The other arrested people may possibly face the offence of "dealing with goods to which the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance applies" under the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance.

The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $1 million and imprisonment of two years.

"There has been an increasing trend of using river trade vessels to smuggle cigarettes into Hong Kong," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department.

From 1996 to 1998, Customs only detected one such case each year with around 1 million illicit cigarettes seized in each case.

"Six such cases have been detected so far this year with 20 million cigarettes seized.

The case detected yesterday was the biggest haul from river trade vessels in one single case," the spokesman added.

Hong Kong Customs is monitoring the situation closely and will devise appropriate enforcement strategy to stem this illicit flow.

"We shall also liaise with our Mainland counterparts for intelligence exchange and enforcement cooperation," he said.
19980723_008.e:
Seizure of dutiable cigarettes by Customs

Customs officers of the Anti-Cigarette-Smuggling Task Force (ACSTF) seized a total of 1.61 million dutiable cigarettes and arrested three suspects in the past two days.

Yesterday afternoon, Customs officers of ACSTF neutralised a distribution ring which supplied dutiable cigarettes to retail outlets in East Kowloon.

A storage centre in a Yau Tong industrial building was smashed with the seizure of 0.5 million sticks of cigarettes valued at $0.65 million.

The seizure has a duty potential of $0.38 million.

Two men were arrested when they were removing cigarettes from the store located in a flat of an industrial building in Yau Tong.

The two arrested will be charged with "dealing with goods to which the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance applies" under the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance.

The maximum penalties for the offence are a fine of $1 million and imprisonment for two years.

In another development, Customs officers seized from a river trading vessel 1.11 million sticks of cigarettes and arrested the shipmaster in the afternoon of July 21 (Tuesday).

The seizure is valued about $1.4 million and has a duty potential of $0.85 million.

In the first five months of this year, the Customs and Excise Department seized about 38 million sticks cigarettes with a market value of more than $50 million and a duty potential of $28.6 million.
19990120_017.e:
Seizure of dutiable cigarettes by Customs

Customs officers yesterday (Tuesday) smashed a distribution centre of contraband cigarettes in San Po Kong following the seizure of 1.36 million dutiable cigarettes.

The seized goods carried a market value of $1.78 million and a duty potential of $1.05 million.

"This was the second significant seizure of dutiable cigarettes effected by the Department in the past five days.

The first case involved the seizure of 9.58 million cigarettes in Kwai Chung Container Terminal last Friday (January 15)," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department.

Following intensive investigations, Customs officers of Anti-Cigarette-Smuggling Task Force yesterday raided an industrial unit in San Po Kong.

As a result, they made the seizure and arrested two men, including an overstayer from the Mainland.

The arrested, aged 27 and 42, will be jointly charged with "Dealing with goods to which the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance applies" under the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance.

The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $1 million and imprisonment for two years.

"The Department will continue its vigorous enforcement actions to check the supply of dutiable cigarettes to show the determination in protecting public revenue," the spokesman added.
19980520_009.e:
Seizure of dutiable cigarettes by Customs

Customs officers smashed a smuggled cigarettes mobile storage centre and arrested a suspect following the seizure of 430,000 sticks of dutiable cigarettes in Sha Tin today (Wednesday).

The value of the seizure is $645,000, with a duty potential of $330,000.

Acting on information, officers from Customs Marine and Land Enforcement Command followed their target in Shek Mun, Sha Tin.

At about 2.30 pm, the officers swang into action when seeing the suspect handling cartons of dutiable cigarettes on board a goods vehicle.

"We believe that we have smashed a syndicate active in the distribution of smuggled cigarettes in Sha Tin and Tsuen Wan," a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department said.

The arrested, a 21-year-old man, will be charged with "dealing with goods to which the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance applies".

The goods vehicle is being impounded pending forfeiture.

The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $1 million and imprisonment for two years.

The spokesman stressed that the department was determined to take all efforts to repress all kinds of cigarettes smuggling activities.
19990830_015.e:
Seizure of dutiable cigarettes by Customs

Speedy action by Customs officers led to the seizure of more than 1.1 million sticks of dutiable cigarettes, which carried a market value of $1.45 million, and a duty potential of about $890,000, in the new Territories last Thursday (August 26).

Acting on self-developed investigations, Customs Officers of the Marine and Land Enforcement Command intercepted three light goods vehicles at a Yuen Long carpark at about 12:50 pm on that day.

As a result, they arrested a 21-year-old man and seized 850,000 contraband cigarettes from three vehicles.

Acting on follow-up enquiries, Customs Officers made a further seizure of 310,000 sticks of dutiable cigarettes, at an open space in Shek Kong about three hours later.

The suspect has been charged with related offences and will appear in Tuen Mun Court on September 24.

"Anyone found in breach of the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance is liable to a maximum fine of$1 million and imprisonment of two years," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department.

"The Department will continue its vigorous enforcement actions to check the supply of dutiable cigarettes to show the determination in protecting public revenue," the spokesman stressed.

Meanwhile, the Customs appealed for information on smuggling of cigarettes.

Information could be passed to the Customs hotline 2545 6182.
19990409_015.e:
Seizure of dutiable cigarettes by Customs

Customs officers yesterday (Thursday) seized 1.75 million sticks of dutiable cigarettes, which carried a market value of $2.3 million and a duty potential of $1.3 million, in Tai Po.

Acting on intelligence, Customs Officers of the Anti-cigarettes Smuggling Task Force raided a premises in Tai Po, believed to be a distribution centre of contraband cigarettes.

As a result, they made the seizure and arrested a 22-year-old man and a 45-year-old woman.

"The dutiable cigarettes for distribution to retail outlets in Sha Tin and most in Kowloon," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department.

The arrested persons have been charged under the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance.

The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $1 million and imprisonment of two years.

"The Department will continue its vigorous enforcement actions to check the supply of dutiable cigarettes to show the determination in protecting public revenue," the spokesman stressed.

Deadline for Hong Kong Flower Show Photo Competition

People who have taken good photos during the 1999 Hong Kong Flower Show and are interested to take part in the Flower Show Photo Competition are reminded to send in their masterpieces before the entry deadline on April 9, 1999 (Friday).

The competition, jointly organised by the Provisional Regional Council, Provisional Urban Council and the Television Broadcasts Limited, is one of the major activities of the 1999 Hong Kong Flower Show.

The competition is divided into three groups -- Group A "Posing by TVB artistes and Miss Hong Kong titleholders" (Open Section and School Section), Group B "Flora" and Group C "Others".

Group A entries should be photos taken at the posing session by TVB artistes and Miss Hong Kong titleholders on March 16 at Sha Tin Park.

Photos taken at the showground during the show period from March 12 to 21 can enter either the Group B or Group C competitions.

All entries should be colour prints in 8R size and attached with a negative.

No mounting is needed for the entries.

The winners will be awarded trophies, cameras and photo developing cash coupons.

All entries should be sent to the Information Division at 17th Floor, Regional Council Building, 1-3 Pai Tau Street, Sha Tin or given to staff at all Fotomax outlets.

The judging session will be held on April 23, 1999 (Friday).

All winning entries will be displayed at Sha Tin Town Hall, Tsuen Wan Town Hall, Kowloon Park and Hong Kong Park, right after the Prize Presentation Ceremony in May.
